De Niro and Hathaway - together at last! Did not expect to like this as much as I did. Goofy, broad comedy mixed with heavy personal drama, with some reasonably interesting things to say about gender roles and the role of the elderly in modern society. But it's really the two heavyweight leads who make it so watchable. Sure, De Niro's golden age is behind him, but the depth and nuance he brings to kindly old gent Ben (played with subtlety, as this is obviously a less showy role than the Bickles and LaMottas) show that he still very much has the chops - he makes the role his own to the point that it's impossible to imagine another actor playing it. The Way is typically riveting, switching between the light and heavy with her usual skill. The movie has kind of a sitcom premise, but manages to rise above it to be a surprisingly affecting platon-com (patent pending).
Eh. Alright but I had hoped it would be more comedy ish

The Film is nicely shot, composed and put together, Ann Hathaway puts on a great performance I like her more and more as an actress definitely grade A but I don't think this film has a the right message that it's ok to over work and not make time or some time for your families and not expect a negative outcome because of it, or maybe I'm just over thinking things. The movie isn't shy about feminism but frankly I find it to be nonsense since Entrepreneurs who don't make time for their families male or female usually struggle in their relationships. It's kind of the case with a lot of successful male Entrepreneurs since Entrepreneurship became a thing. The film though is a great insight into the lives of Entrepreneurs, they tend to put it more hours running their business than their employees, again regardless of a persons sex it's generally the same story for a lot if not all young business upstarts.

I recently watched the movie" The Intern," and I think the movie is great. The chemistry between Robert and Anne is so fabulous. Despite I thought the movie was a comedy movie at first, it is a really warm and fragrant one that tears wear up in my eyes at the end of the movie. Robert is so cute and he interpreted Ben really well. Although being aged, Ben still wanted to gain something in his late life. He applied an intern for Anne's company not just because he wanted to do something but he wanted to be needed. He gave advices to Julie and people all around him, in other words, he was a wise man and very experienced in everything that people would encounter in their long life journey. Sometimes you expect so hard and eagerly to show up a person who can give you advices to you when you have a hard time and I regarded Ben as the sage in this movie. Compare with Julie and Ben, life could be busy in former and could be hopeless and depressed in later, but watched how they hit a balance between their lives by learning from each other. I highly recommend "The Intern," to all of my friends and you guys and I found umm... Nancy Meyers is a director that could really show gentle and subtle of the character and the playbook she wrote. Love the movie love Robert De Niro so much.

Sure to be a classic. The Intern is a clean comedy movie that is actually fairly funny (rare thing these days) with a likeable cast. And even when it's not being directly funny it's enjoyable to watch. Probably best of all, is that it doesn't follow a typical formula, like so many movies these days. Only complaint is that the ending felt kind of abrupt and unsatisfying. With that said, I'm not sure how I would have done it differently either, so I have respect for the guts taken to end it there, when there was really nowhere else for it to go.

The Intern is a cute comedy with lovable lead performances from Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway. De Niro plays a true gentleman in this movie, the kind of great guy we all strive to be. He plays this perfectly and I loved him in the role. Hathaway could be annoying at times, but thats goes great with her character and growth. Her strong friendship with De Niro is the highlight of the film and it completely works. The humor was extremely fun and it didn't feel forced, it flowed well with the characters. My only real issue is that the movie isn't really original. While it has a fun concept, the movie doesn't try to be anything different or new. It goes down exactly as you expect. But I really enjoyed The Intern, and I enjoyed seeing De Niro and Hathaway together even more.
It's a cute and sort of quirky movie that you just don't see anymore.

Without knowing too much about the plot, I assumed this was taking De Niro down a familiar trodden path of another "Fokker" type role. How wrong I was! This is a very endearing, gentle and easily watchable escapade that sees an ageing De Niro being given an internship with an e-commerce fashion company and becoming surprisingly useful at bestowing his considerable knowledge to his new colleagues. I can't remember ever seeing De Niro play such a likable role without seemingly any flaws to his character. Hathaway charms her way through the film and there's a nice cameo from Russo as a love interest. A film that doesn't try too hard to be funny and comes across better for it.

Nancy Myers directs and writes her next film in the Intern. Anne Hathaway who played the clueless intern in the Devil Wears Prada now plays a CEO of her own company. The intern this time, is the 70 year old Rober Dinero. Unfortunately Myers feels this premise is a lot funnier than it actually is and relies on this too heavily. The film relies on the typical jokes you would expect, many of which being an elderly person and their battle with new technology. The intern has some charm at first, but gets repetitive and really does not use the situation to offer much character development. The supporting characters offer the majority of the comedy, and scenes such as breaking into a house to delete an email come off as forced. The Intern feels long, and is not one of Myer's best.

The Intern: The latest film by director Nancy Meyers could have easy slipped into the realm of predictable, emotionally-manipulative schlock fest, were it not for the unlikely chemistry of its immensely likable stars, Anne Hathaway and Robert Deniro, who, as an over stressed owner of an Internet startup and the senior intern looking for meaning in his golden years, will have you rooting for them all the way to its oh-so-sweet ending. I had high hopes for this movie but it kinda let me down. The movie really doesn't establish much of a dramatic arc for Deniro's character-he's unhappy and then he becomes an intern and becomes almost imediatly happy, that's about the gist of it. Rather than the idea that both generations have a lot to teach each other, Meyers seems to think that it's a one way street, with the old sage guy handing down advice to a thirty something employee. This does not make for a very engaging picture, especially since Deniro's character is supposed to be the main character. The movie also really can't decide who's Hatthaway's character should be, we meet her as a quirky boss who rides a bike within her office and accidently gives her phone number to a disgruntles client. but at the same time the movie also wants to make her inspire fear in employees similar to how Meryl Streep did in The Devil Wears Prada and the movie can not make these elements work in tandem. It's not all bad, the tech comany seems like a fun place and you do want to hang around these characters, but from a story telling perspective it's really weak, which makes the film seem overly long.

While this will never win any awards, it's a good Sunday-afternoon-on-the-sofa movie.

"Um Senhor Estagiário" conta a história de Ben (Robert De Niro), profissional veterano, que consegue o trabalho de estagiário numa empresa que vende roupas pela internet, criada pela empresária Jules (Anne Hathaway). O filme mostra o ambiente do mundo corporativo e o convívio de pessoas de gerações diferentes, mostrando como a união de diversas competências (experiência, resiliência, ousadia e criatividade) é fundamental para o sucesso de um negócio. O filme da diretora Nancy Meyers também fala sobre relações humanas e como podemos melhorar, ou nos adequar, a vários tipos de situações, sem perder a nossa identidade.

SPOILER ALERT So, I just got done watching The Intern featuring the ever charming Robert De Niro and exemplary Anne Hathaway. (Not to mention the ever suave Rene Russo). I have some kudos to give and a word of authorship to the script writers for the movie. 1. The movie was incredibly heart felt. It touched me in all the right places. It was sincere and earnest and never felt like it was over done or campy. The actors fell into their roles in cadence and it transported me from the beginning to the end, with ease. 2. Robert De Niro aced his performance. The movie seemed to be written with an intimate knowledge of Mr. De Niro's previous performances and ability to transcend traditional roles. I dare to say this movie may have missed its mark all together with an alternate selection for the lead. 3. Anne Hathaway and Rene Russo were charming. I'm sure it wasn't easy for Ms. Russo to take a backseat to another leading lady. But she did so with charm and finesse and her character took on the challenge of a supporting role and did so with grace. 4. The movie was heartfelt and plucked the right strings. We felt the change of loyalty and even the butterflies of forgiveness. But...and this is a very strong but... (SPOILER ALERT) The writer missed a huge huge moment to take this movie to a whole other emotional plane of existence. Ms. Hathaway is at her wit's end trying to save a troubled relationship with her husband. So, she is trying to fill a vital role of CEO at her burgeoning company. Finally, she flies, with the company of Mr. De Niro, out to San Fransisco to meet one final and promising candidate for the position. After her interview with the potential CEO, she joins Mr. De Niro in the car that is bound for their return flight to NY. He asks her how it went. She goes on to profess how he was Smart and Kind and totally took her by surprise. The moment was so endearing, I felt the butterflies rise from my stomach and the tears begin to peak at the corners of my eye. Hope against hope I was waiting for her to extend her hand to Mr. De Niro and say, "Congratulations CEO!" That would have wrung my heart and made me fall head over heels in love with this movie, in a way unknown to me since Free Willy. Did it happen that way? Nope. The movie dragged to make a quick recovery of Ms. Hathaway's failing relationship and ended on a furiously paced band aid for her broken heart. Come on Hollywood Screen Writers! You get paid the big bucks, your duty is to elevate your audience. This was a fantastic movie but you missed the big finale! All critique aside, thanks for a touching tale with a few laughs and surprises along the way. And a challenge to Big Hollywood, think outside the box, for once! - @josephamichael

The Intern won't redefine cinema, not that it's meant to, but it's a sweet and clever crowd-pleaser that works equally well as a comedy and also dramatically, mainly due to the pairing of Hathaway and De Niro. With some genuinely insightful dialogue, a number of truly funny bits of physical business, and small scenes allowing us to get know and like a half-dozen supporting players, The Intern grows us on from scene to scene, from moment to moment. A poignant, character-based comedy about professional passion, the struggle to retain a healthy work-life balance, and how the unlikeliest of friendships can sometimes become the most meaningful. De Niro and Hathaway are a surprisingly perfect pairing. Nancy Meyers delivers another funny, warm, smart and sophisticated comedy for adults that features Robert De Niro in perhaps his most likeable performance ever. De Niro is his usual charming best and Hathaway takes what could have been a one-dimensional character and breathes life into her. The success of this film may ride entirely on the alchemy of these particular actors, but whatever is carrying it, The Intern gets there. With The Intern, Meyers has made another bright, contemporary American comedy with a lot on its mind - and works hard to make it look effortless. These days, it's tough to find a comedy that even aspires to sophistication. The Intern entertainingly fills that slot VERDICT: "High-Quality Stuff" - [Positive Reaction] This is a rating to a movie I view as very entertaining and well made, and definitely worth paying the full price at a theatre to see or own on DVD. It is not perfect, but it is definitely excellent. (Films that are rated 3.5 or 4 stars)

Movie Review Maven Grade: B In a Nutshell: Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway are some of my faves . Other faces you'll enjoy seeing are the beautiful Rene Russo, Adam DeVine, and Andrew Rannells. While the premise of this comedy is very sweet with great comic potential, the writing doesn't reach very far. It's pleasant, but bland; sweet, but forgettable. Director Nancy Meyers charms, yet plays it safe. Uplifting Theme: · Everyone wants to feel wanted, needed, and relevant. · "You're never wrong to do the right thing." - Mark Twain · Men, always carry a handkerchief. You'll look classy and be a hero to someone someday. Things I liked: · I loved Ben Whitaker's (Robert De Niro) video application and the fact that he admitted that he had to call his 6 year old grandson to find out what a USB port was. Ha ha · I liked the way Jules' (Anne Hathaway) office worked. For example, the receptionist was really personable and friendly. I like the idea of ringing a bell and offering applause whenever someone in the office does something well. · Anne Hathway has such a beautiful smile. · Rene Russo is aging so beautifully. I take that back....she's not aging at all. · I loved how Ben saw a problem and fixed it without fanfare (when he cleans up the giant mess on the company junk desk). Years ago I worked for a Congressman in Washington DC, hoping to make big contributions in American politics. One day, I cleaned the office kitchenette, because, frankly, it was disgusting and no one else was doing it. While I had wanted to save the world, the thing that everyone praised me the most for was being the one who actually took the time to clean the messy kitchen area. Ha ha If you want to stand out, do something that others aren't willing to do. · Overall, it's a clean date movie, which is refreshing in the wake of trashy movies like Trainwreck - If you enjoyed The Devil Wears Prada , Anne Hathaway's character in this movie will feel familiar, as if Andy grew up and started her own fashion business. Things I didn't like: · It's pretty predictable. No big plot twists or surprises. · Robert De Niro's character is a little one-dimensional, with a goofy grin on his face most of the time. - A few amusing scenarios, but nothing laugh-out-loud funny. · The movie preaches about having it all. Can you really have it all? Years ago I attended the Governor'sConference for Women in California (fantastic event) and that very question was asked of several high-powered women on a panel. They all chimed in about how you CAN, until finally, Meg Whitman (CEO of Ebay) honestly said it wasn't true. She explained that you can't have it all....at the same time. For example, one day you can be the best business woman in the world, but then the house work is going to slide or else you're too exhausted at the end of the day to carry on a meaningful conversation with your spouse. Another day you can be Super Mom, but then you won't have time to exercise or pay your bills. Ultimately, there are only so many hours in a day and something usually has to give. I appreciated the honesty of that answer and it has always helped me to set more realistic expectations about my day. Funny lines: · "What did you major in? Do you remember?" - ATF Interviewer #1 (Wallis Currie-Wood) · "Grey is the new green." - Jason (funny man Adam DeVine from Pitch Perfect ) Things to look for: · In the beginning of the movie when Jules rides her bicycle through the office, they had to have her ride extra slowly so the two girls could get all of their lines out during the scene. · Ben's closet is pretty awesome. · Here is a question for you: If you knew someone was having an affair, would you tell the spouse? Is it your place to? Would it help them or hurt them? Tips for Parents: · Jason hands Ben a newspaper to cover up his private parts when he's getting a massage. · Two F-bombs, but they're both mouthed and so you can't hear it. Someone flips the bird. · Jules and Ben watch the movie An American in Paris , which your kids probably haven't seen. It's a classic you should introduce to them! (On second thought, was it a clip from Singin' in the Rain ?) · Pre-marital relations.

This was a fun twist from the usual approach to comedies dealing with generational differences. The cast is top-notch and the story is more than just the light fluff expected from these comedies.

The Intern avoids two major cliches. It does not turn De Niro's character into a joke in a 'what's-that-old-man-doing-here?' way you might expect, and downplays his thin technology skills. That is it does exactly the opposite of what the recent 'intern' comedy about Google did a few short months ago, and opts instead to tell an actual story about people. It also avoids another major cliche that goes to the heart of the plot, so I can't reveal it. So while this film is not an earth shattering moment in the history of cinema, it quietly goes about its business in a more intelligent way than most mainstream comedies (dramadies) and I appreciated that. Though it takes acting talent as good as Hathaway and De Niro to pull something like that off. When you don't get your mileage out of stuffed bears giving the finger, little dogs jumping out of windows, or people accidentally lighting their hair on fire, you find yourself in a situation where you actually have to act - because all the absurd distractions common to today's comedies are absent. Hathaway and De Niro pulled it off with great skill.

Writer and director Nancy Meyers continues to display her abilities in both roles with THE INTERN. Meyers' work is polished in every regard. Perhaps the silliness of certain moments in the script reaches what feels like great stretches in the aesthetic framework of the movie, these moments also constitute what are arguably necessary beats for the whole show to be dramatically effective. Meyers is unmistakably purposeful. She is, however, clearly not writing for everyone. As critic reviews will bring out, THE INTERN is not as nuanced as some would like it to be. For her intended audience, though, the movie hits all the right emotional notes while still leaving them with bits of wisdom to chew on. Specifically, THE INTERN does not simply make fun of differences resulting from age gaps (although it does capitalize on some generational disconnects for several amusing moments), but reminisces and then proposes that some "old ways" of doing things may still be valuable. Essentially, the young are reminded to learn from their elders. The "moral" of the movie can certainly be complicated beyond that, but the afore-mentioned theme gets at the gist of the values that can be excavated from the picture. DeNiro and Hathaway have excellent chemistry and their on-screen relationship seems comforting and maybe a little familiar without feeling cliche or worn out. Their performances breathe life into Meyers' script that may have come off as less interesting in the hands of other actors. THE INTERN does not particularly break new artistic ground, but it is none-the-less fun, wise, and emotionally satisfying.
As far as predictable pseudo-father/daughter vaguely rom-com-y fare goes, this one wasn't half bad.

Few movies will enthrall you like stroking in a feather, lets you feel a gentle breeze and to go back to bed with a quiet mind like a pristine lake. This is one such movie. It throws many good things for everyone to learn, understand and live but you will see them in the movie only if you want to. I could not say just a few things - there were many. The story line was pretty straight. Is Jules going to run her dreams by saying no to a ceo or stays back and let a ceo in. As an audience you feel saying it in the very beginning of the movie itself like "Come on jules you can do it !!". But that not how its going to work in real life. To advise others is the easiest thing to do. You might knew what's right for your friend but we miss to see the situation from their shoes. You should wait for them to realize and analyze the crisis and let them swim it. And that's what ben does and the character was scripted as on how a matured and righteous person will react to every situation. When davis had problem to find a place he didn't offer his home right away, he did let him find things by himself but when he had no other option other than leaving the place, he offered help to share his home. Ben felt bad seeing matt having an affair and could not say it to her. Marvelous acting by Robert De Niro. You cannot hide all your emotions and he revealed that in a great acting. After seeing matts affair, when in office where jules and everyone finds out that ben is disturbed - Ben could not swallow and digest what he saw and could not spit the same out. Revealing it to Jules and might have had egregious consequences in her life. But when jules finds it out, he was there to listen and talk with her. Dialogues were crucial there. He didn't advise even a bit anywhere about the situation. He asked not to worry as she can be burried next to him. Consoling with a magical touch. Even when jules stopped by his home in the end of the movie - he delivers his thought on why she should run a company in a pleasing way stating you might have taken that decision by now but you stopped by here to see me to get an assertion that you are making the right decision. That was so awesome. He didn't advise on that topic throught out the movie. Few would have advised the moment they over heard the conversation jules had in conference room. The character of ben is a summation of maturity and all goodness that a human being should possess. Listening to people, helping when needed, clean up things even if its others mess without ego, never stop to learn new things, respect fellow human being, never forget to laugh, what empathy is, when to talk, how to handle a crisis in life, respecting your spouse and to be happy with what you have got. Awesome work by director for coming up with such a script. This is a movie to preserve.

THE INTERN starts off as retired but bored Robert De Niro joins a vibrant web start up headed by the workaholic Anne Hathaway. The idea is cute and the jokes write themselves. But unlike many movies based on unusual premises, this movie quickly moves on from the quirkiness of the pair up to bring us a truly moving and interesting story. The two stars are firing on all cylinders throughout the movie. Their relationship, acting chops and a good script manage the feat of conveying Hathaway's intricate - and not entirely predictable - character development in an unusually believable manner. There is one particular scene - during their business trip - featuring just the two stars where I felt like I was seeing some of the best acting I have seen all year. And while De Niro and Hathaway are brilliant, a charming supporting cast also surrounds them. I particularly like this movie due to the male/female role reversal in Hathaway's personal life that we also saw in this year's TRAINWRECK. While THE INTERN deals with a different slice of life as Schumer's summer comedy, we once again find the pattern of a woman living in what was traditionally a male role. This time that of a harried, passionate entrepreneur who struggles to keep up with the success of her start-up while simultaneously attempting to balance family and work. THE INTERN will not get any awards or even nomination and will most likely not be remember in the annals of movie history. But it is a great example of a movie that is everything it could be. So if the premise intrigues you, and the trailer seems like something you might enjoy, then I can guarantee you will enjoy it.

The Hollywood film industry is stuck in a bubble. I watched "The Intern" on my flight home --- wow. Aside from the usual outrageously racist casting (par for the course in Hollywood: almost every employee is white, not a single East Asian employee as far as the eye can see --- in a tech startup with 200+ employees?) The storyline is filled with anachronisms pasted over startup cliches ... yes, it's open-plan, but the female CEO has a giant, walled-off office cut off from the rest of the floor (fairly uncommon for early stage startups). She has a secretary (!) who follows her around and reminds her of her schedule. The investors want to bring in an outside CEO, despite the fact that the company is wildly successful. The female CEO needs to have a condescending talk from her (white) male subordinate about how she needs to cede authority to an older (male) CEO to take over for her. She rides a bike around the office, but has a private chauffeur to take her to and from work in a giant SUV. Her husband is a stay-at-home husband, because, of course, if you have children, one parent must stay at home, and if the wife works that means the husband has to give up his career --- because two-parent working families are out of the question. She's supposed to be a startup CEO but she can't figure out how to turn off the keyboard clicks on her iPhone. It's set in 2015, but all the tropes seem to be from some version of the 1940's, except with glass walls and laptops instead of typewriters. The film industry is increasingly isolated, cut off from the rest of the world --- I suppose it's always been that way, but there's something really lazy about the insularity of it, particularly in a rapidly changing world. The vapid recycling of outdated tropes, the lack of anything but the most superficial research into anything outside their preconceived notions of social and economic changes, the lack of engagement with contemporary issues, it's really sad. The casual racism of nearly-all-white casting (Asians typically make up about 1/3rd of startup staff, yet in Hollywood, we're nowhere to be seen) is just one of many bizarre disconnects between reality and Hollywood. It is such an important industry, it literally creates the dreams of our civilization, yet they're increasingly cut off from the day to day lives of people working in anything they are unfamiliar with.

The Intern is a interesting little comedy\drama that centers on a retired man played by Deniro who interns for young CEO Hathaway. It has a few funny moments and some great performance from its leads and its supporting cast but there isn't much of a story here. It drags along and doesn't have a satisfying enough ending. The Intern was a refreshing change of pace for me, theatrically speaking. A story with a heart, solid acting and quite a bit of realism. I love DeNiro and Hathaway anyway, but the chemistry between the two was very strong. The performances won't get recognized at the award level, but I haven't enjoyed DeNiro this much in a long time. It was a departure for him and he was precious. The vibe of the film was reminiscent of similarly-themed 80s and 90s films, but I haven't really seen anything like this in almost 20 years. They just don't make these kind of movies anymore. For someone my age, it was a pleasure to watch.

I think all of this makes it a decent flick. It did not sync up with my experience regarding either demographic (older retired and young hip), but it did make me want to appreciate both. The Intern (2015) is a drama/comedy film starring Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway. This film has a more realistic today's generation family business story which actually hits home in my life. The movie was well put together and the cast could have not been any more perfectly selected for such a film. The Intern (2015) brings good classy comedy to the table while taking you through the day to day of a 70 year old intern in the tech world. This film does have it's usual styling or theme as all other films within this genre/classification though it does have a nice spark to make it stand out from many. The Intern (2015) is enjoyable for all ages and didn't come slam packed with innuendos and quick one liners like most of the films from the last decade. I tip my hat to those who worked hard to make a very well produced classy comedy.

Cute and heartwarming on a number of levels, this film was nearly perfect (a few of the masseuse scenes were unnecessary and some of the plot twists were cliche). I'm not sure what I like most about this movie. It could be its perfect casting choices. It could be its natural and clever dialogue. It could be highlighting the importance of classical "manhood". At any rate, it shows that all generations have something to offer and once we get past the preconceived notions about a person, we can see what value they truly hold.

Boring and pandering, The Intern - despite telling a story as languid and cliche as its protagonist - is all over the place. It feels predominantly like an old-folks' flick (i.e. Exotic Marigold Hotel, Philomena, etc.), oh but suddenly you've got some gentle douche humor from all of the workaholics, oh and you've got Anne Hathaway, an 'e-commerce' (whatever THAT is) mogul. Why? Because women be shoppin' I had one obsessive, recurring thought running through my mind, and I think it made me bristle more at every pleasantly retarded little moment - this is Travis Bickle. This is Travis. Fuggin'. Bickle.

Didn't know what to expect from this movie but I knew with Robert Di Niro and Anne Hathaway in it the movie had to be funny at least. It was and it was every other emotion too. Being older and having lost his wife he was able to be a mentor to all the younger male inters as well as others in the office. There was a line of the movie that stuck with me and rings true. I'm not good at quoting but it was something like this. When did men stop being men and remain little boys? We stopped calling women girls but why did we stop using the word gentlemen? Then she looks at the 3 guys that are also interns as well as Ben (Di Niro) and they are dressed in casual rather sloppy clothes and he is wearing a suit and tie. Looks very nice IMO and I have to agree with her. That MEN are a dying breed and they're being replaced by boys. She wasn't making a feminist statement, it's that at all. Women WANT MEN, we don't want 40 year old boys who still dress like they're in college and play video games! So I loved that she and Ben had become friends not just work colleagues. That was my favorite thing about this movie and probably why I enjoyed it so much. He may be retired but he still has a life and a purpose. People NEED him. I really liked they showed that senior adults still have very active social lives after they retire because SO MANY in my generation seem to think once you hit a certain age, everything I guess just stops? Had this exact discussion with a 41YO guy from high school just a few weeks ago and was floored by his ignorance because he's actually rather intelligent. Book smart not common sense smart. He wasn't the first to make such an asinine statement. Having been my MIL caregiver this movie reminded me of her and my Mammaw because they both had more active social lives in their late 60s than I did in my late 30s! The reason is they were single and I'm married so I don't go out with a different man to a dance or movie or dinner. LOVED that Ben took his first date to a FUNERAL! I died laughing when he gave the lady chasing him the "I'm sorry" look!

Robert De Niro has graced movie goers with his presence for fifty years. We have seen him play mobsters, lunatics, a comedian, protective father, and many more. In the The Intern, we are able to see him play someone new. Although known for his "tough guy" roles, De Niro finally plays a softy. Ben (De Niro) is a retired widower looking to fill in an empty part of his life. He applies for a senior intern position at an e-commerce fashion company, About the Fit. He is accepted. Ben gets paired with Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway), the busy founder of About the Fit who barely has anytime to even eat. Jules is a very independent, self made women who believes an intern can only be a distraction. She soon discovers Ben's great work ethic and caring ways. Eventually Ben becomes more than just the intern as the two form a friendship. Going into this film I was not excepting much, but The Intern ended up being my favorite feel good comedy of the year. De Niro gives a performance that is so warm, you can compare it to your favorite blanket. Ben is a man filled with empathy and wisdom, the ideal grandpa and mentor. Ben carried such kindness with him, it will be hard re-watching De Niro in his mobster roles. Anne Hathaway also gives a sincere and heartfelt performance. She divides her time with being a mother, wife, and running a company. Just like Ben, I really cared about Jules and wanted her to be happy. There is amazing chemistry between De Niro and Hathaway. Completely platonic, almost like a father/daughter relationship. During the film it felt like I had a inside look at their lives. We were able to follow Ben and Jules morning, afternoon, and night. Because of this, I became very attached to these characters. There lives seemed so real. Much like Ben, I am a softy at heart. Once again, director Nancy Meyers has reminded me of that.

Like all sensible human beings, I'm a huge Robert De Niro fan; it's no wonder The Intern piqued my interest. Alas, De Niro's character is far and away supersedes competing elements of this flick. Simply put, there's not enough substance or climax in The Intern to totally win the filmgoer over. Inexplicably, the plot shifts focus from DeNiro's Ben to Anne Hathaway's Jules midway through and never looks back. Transposition is a tricky ingredient in the recipe for cinematic success, and it only works a small percentage of the time. Nancy Myers' new film is in the failing majority.

What can I say but what a fantastically nice movie. Nothing amazing happens, excitement was left out when the screenplay was written. What you are delivered is 2 hours of positive affirmations from Robert DeNiro that he "still has music left in him" and Anne Hathaway looking, acting, succeeding and struggling like most of out generation and the issues in following your dreams and not being able to delegate. The small and simple things in this movie make you smile on so many occasions that the characters jump out at you and you can't help but feel for them. I had expectations for how the story would go and my only complaint is that it would have been good to see the results of all the advice he gave to the interns around the office while he was waiting for his email. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who wants a nice calm and enjoyable movie with two fantastic actors who slip into characters as if they were already them.

This movie was great. There was a great use of camera angles and symbolism. The story was original with many plot twists making it all the more better. Being a feminist, I enjoyed seeing a woman in power and addressing the issues of feminism throuout the movie. It really brought attention to an untraditional household and made the situation seem realistic and a good thing. However, there was one specific part in the movie that I couldn't stop thinking about. In one scene, Matt, Paige, Jules, and Ben are in the Ostin's kitchen when Paige tells her parents that Maddy doesn't want to be her friend anymore and Matt calls Maddy bipolar on account of the fact that every other day she is has an issue with Paige. Children often have mood swings as they are trying to figure out how to deal with their emotions. Bipolar disorder is not something to joke about because lots of people struggle with this very serious mental health issue. I would highly suggest that the producers decide to edit out the few lines that have to do with calling Maddy bipolar as many people could take offense to it. This is the only reason I did not give five stars. Other than that one scene, the movie was great and I highly recommend it!

Let me start off by saying that I love Robert De Niro. I am a huge fan of his, even if some of the recent movies he has starred in haven't been so good, I still think he is a great actor. Ok, now that, that is out of the way, let's get this review started. The performances in The Intern are very good. Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway have amazing chemistry in this film. It's no Jake Gyllenhall and Michael Pena but it's still amazing. Robert De Niro is very charming in this movie. I'm not the biggest Anne Hathaway fan but she really did surprise me in this. She was really good and really believable. The Intern is really funny, specifically a break-in scene that had me crying. That scene was hilarious! I was debating whether to give this a 3.5 star rating but when I looked back on that scene, I knew I had to give it a 4 star. The drama was really good too. My only complaint was that it didn't know what it was trying to be. Did it want to be a comedy or a drama? I'm not saying you can't have "dramedy". It just had me laughing at one point, then sad, then laughing, then sad again. Another complaint I had was the pacing, it wasn't very fast but it wasn't very slow. There were a few scenes that dragged on for a bit to long and there were parts where I was checking my watch. There are a few boring/dull scenes here and there but for the most part, I had a blast watching this. It has a little bit of comedy, drama, and a lot of heart. See it!

Just back from "The Intern." Very enjoyable. Just a "nice" film; I don't mean that insultingly... it was just relentlessly... nice. Even when Anne Hathaway's character has a major crisis, it still wraps up in pretty much the nicest way possible. That being said, Hathaway and De Niro have great, weird chemistry together, and that's the enjoyable part of the film. De Niro is seemingly effortless in this, but it's a good effortless as opposed to some of his "I'm phoning this in for the money" type of "effortless" you see from him some times these days. In the end, it's a Nancy Meyers film... she has a certain style and it's probably not going to change. However, I really enjoyed watching both De Niro and Hathaway do their thing... good work by some of the supporting characters... sometimes that's just enough. RATING: 4/5 RT, 8/10 IMDB.

I had little to no expectations going into THE INTERN, but boy was I pleasantly surprised after leaving the theater. THE INTERN is a happy and incredibly enjoyable time at the movies. With a pretty simple premise, De Niro and Hathaway shine as these two lovable characters in an unconventional situation. Hathaway is a young CEO of a start-up internet clothing store that simply wants to please everyone. Her busy schedule and lack of business experience make it difficult to manage all of the responsibilities as CEO and a mother. The performance by Hathaway manages o show this so you can't help but like her. This type of progressive character is need more in film. Women being the breadwinner is becoming more and more popular and society and this character portrays it very well. As good as Hathaway is in THE INTERN, Robert De Niro shines the brightest as the 70 year old intern. His portrayal of Ben Whitaker is what made him one of the most lovable characters in recent film. He does whatever it takes to make everyone's day better around him. De Niro's surprising chemistry with Hathaway is what makes this movie fun. On screen these two actually feel like best friends and even like father and daughter. They both help better each other over the course of the movie and do it in a way which seems natural and unforced. All in all, with a simple story, the chemistry between Anne Hathaway and Robert De Niro create a feel-good and happy movie that is an overall good time at the movies. (3.75/5)

Lo nuevo de la directora Nancy Meyers es una de las comedias más divertidas y entrañables del año, toda una grata sorpresa. Contando la historia de un hombre retirado que se inscribe en un programa de pasantes mayores en una empresa de ropa por internet, con el objetivo de darle sentido a su vida de nuevo. La química entre Robert de Niro y Anne Hathaway es magia pura en pantalla, logrando personajes bastante entrañables y haciendo que la historia funcione perfectamente, incluso me atrevería a decir que ambos o por lo menos Mr. De Niro lograran la nominación al Globo de Oro. A pesar de que ellos sostienen la cinta, los demás personajes no son mal aprovechados y cada uno tiene su momento para brillar, incluyendo a Rene Russo con un divertido personaje. The Intern cumple todo lo que propone, es fresca y es muy divertida, algo que se agradece mucho y que los amantes del genero disfrutaran. Muy recomendable.

The Intern was a refreshing piece of cinema that dealt with the realities of ageism (specifically in the workplace) in a humorous and charming way. The plot was well thought out, well acted, and entertaining. The overarching ideas of feminism and the wisdom of those older than us were well delivered. It was truly a pleasure to see a movie that made me both laugh and cry, something I have not experienced in quite some time from a single movie. Not only will I be purchasing The Intern when it is released, but it has earned the coveted title of "A favorite movie" of mine.

De Niro is genuinely adorable. That's pretty much the highlight of Nancy Meyer's The Intern, a fluffy dramedy about a 70-year-old widower working for Anne Hathaway as an intern. De Niro is absolutely charming, and the mix of comedy and drama works well, but in the end very forgettable and generic.

Nancy Meyers has made a couple of films I have enjoyed, the now fairly forgotten What Women Want, where she got a good performance from Mel Gibson and paired him with an inform Helen Hunt, and then her following film, Something's Gotta Give, where she generated great energy from Jack Nicholson, but also went one better by pairing him with a fantastic Diane Keaton. Her next film, It's Complicated, featured a great performance from Meryl Streep (well, that's expected) but an over the top Alec Baldwin and a series of terrible supporting characters ruined the film. After a long layoff, she's back, and this time she's dragged more energy out of Robert De Niro than many of his recent performances. De Niro is great with comedy and he plays it very well throughout. The humour is not an endless series of 'he's old, he doesn't understand the youngsters and their technology' and they certainly don't try to weave in any romance between him and Hathaway (thank God). But the jokes are consistent and the plot moves along briskly, and deals with just enough depth to lift it above many films of a similar style. Of the rest of the cast, Hathaway is excellent, and like De Niro, effortless. There's a good performance (all be it occasional) from Rene Russo, and the supporting men surrounding De Niro are all fine. However, Holm feels a bit miscast as the husband. He suits the role early as the stay at home dad playing with the daughter, however, in the final act of the movie, he doesn't bring enough depth to the character to hold the weight the scenes required.

The Intern is a movie with a premise that hooked me from the first time I saw a trailer. The idea of 70-year-old Robert De Niro working as an intern at a young up-and-coming business run by Anne Hathaway was great. Thankfully they didn't spend much time on explaining the logic of why they were seeking employees that old, so it just got things rolling early without too much exposition. This is where the movie got my hopes up. It cut right to his hiring pretty quickly, but then it took almost half the movie before De Niro started to have any significant interactions with Hathaway. I thought the movie would be a great look at how the wisdom of our elders can be a valuable tool in the modern workplace, but he doesn't provide as much guidance as I was expecting. There were certainly moments that met my expectations, but they were few and far between. I actually started to wonder why Hathaway's character grew attached to him at all. I also felt they spent way too much time with Hathaway's family, which was the weaker aspect of the movie. I think I know what Nancy Meyers was trying to do (talk about how people still tend to belittle strong working women) but that wasn't the message I expected to be delivered by The Intern. Also, because she intended to focus on that message, it would undermine her strength as a character if De Niro did anything of significance to "save" her. So the theme she was striving for ended up undermining the main premise of the plot. It's a sweet enough movie to watch, and I enjoyed parts of it, but it fell short of my expectations.

This wasn't the most exciting film I have ever seen, nor the funniest. However it did have a certain charm to it. The leads, Anne Hathaway and Robert De Nero, have great chemistry. A nice film but not an amazing one.
Very charming and funny.

Really enjoyed this movie. The acting and chemistry of Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway is great. I'm so used to seeing De Niro play a rough character that it was such a treat to see him play a feel-good role. There is substantial humor for the most part of the film until *semi-spoiler* it takes a more serious tone towards the second half of the film. I recommend it if you want to watch a feel-good comedy movie that touches on perseverance and independence. (10/17/15) Edwards 10

This movie has funny aspects throughout the two hours, however there's no story to follow and therefore you don't have any attachment to a character which becomes boring after half an hour. If you're looking for a chilled out movie that you don't need to pay attention too then this is the movie for you... p.s I've only watched the trailer.

The Intern gets one thing seriously right: the casting of Robert DeNiro. He puts this movie on his shoulders and runs to daylight, milking the best of scenes with expression and nuance. He had me from the first scene, and what a pleasure it was to watch him with Renee Russo as they steal the show. Not a fan of Anne Hathaway and nothing she does here will add to her Oscar hopes. See this one for the veterans; it's one of DeNiro's best performances.

It's not often I get the kind of emotional truth in a movie where I feel like I should leave the room because I'm intruding on the characters, but I felt that way in this movie. It was funny and emotional without being trite and completely subverts expectations.

Set my expectations real low and allowed myself to fully enjoy the film for the nice, light treat that it is. It is very hard for me to give a Deniro comedy a shot but he is quite good in this film as is Anne Hathaway. I ain't no Hatha-hater. I really like her on screen warmth and here she is strong, smart and vulnerable. Only wish the "heist" scene wasn't in the film. Sure, it got good laughs in the theater but it seemed a little cheap and out of character for those involved.

I think I expected myself to fall in love with Anne Hathaway's character and I couldn't because of how phenomenal Deniro's was. I'm really glad that I took the time to see this movie. It was definitely one where I came out of the movie feeling better than when I went in.

Un hombre retirado,viudo y en sus 70's, Ben ( Robert De NIro) decide reincorporarse como pasante de una empresa de modas liderada por una joven ejecutiva, Jules ( Anne Hathaway). Jules, reticente en un primer momento a contar con un pasante de edad avanzada, encontrarà en Ben un aliado valioso para sus proyectos y un amigo leal. Bastante tierna, inteligente y divertida.

FANTASTIC movie!!!! It was heart-warming, funny & it sure shows how much society relies on technology with everything. SO GLAD I went to see it in theaters than just waiting for it to come out on videos!!! When you look at Robert De Niro, you picture him as a tough, smart "Mafia-like" type of character. This movie showed him as the opposite. But when you think of Anne Hathaway, you don't see her as a control-freak, powerful, career-driven like woman. I stead of confronting an employee that she doesn't want around.her she gets her second in command to take care of it. The tired old dilemma of a woman 'wanting it all" is also played. I'm sure the producers patted themselves on the back for having a house husband but then the main character deals with crisis solely because she is a woman. Maybe if Hollywood quit shoving the concept.down our throats people would stop believing women have to make choices that men don't.

Robert de Niro est excellent dans un contre-emploi qui rend parfaitement hommage à son talent, tandis qu'Anne Hathaway est moins insupportable qu'à l'accoutumée. The intern is a confusing movie, both in its (and i hesitate to use this term for fear of shitstorm) gender politics, its slant on experience and the bizarre likability of its two leads. It often shoots, it often misses but overall it is quite endearing and enjoyable. Director Nancy Meyers has been responsible for some of the more cringeworthy 'woman movies' hits including the atrocious 'What women want' but here she turns her eyes towards 'surrogate father' relationships. Because let's not mince words, this is what the Intern is. Real 'man's man' DeNiro is contrasted to the way these 'manchildren playing videogames these days' are, they dress like slobs, can't talk to women and don't carry pocket squares. DeNiro is a bastion of old masculinity, an embodiment of the middle class america of youre and he becomes endearing to the millennial hipster crowd by sheer can-do-ness and seriousness. Kids these days amirite? And in that process he becomes a surrogate masculine figure for quirky, overworked, overachieving start-up founder Hathaway. And this is where the politics get confusing, at least for me as a man with sympathies for feminism. Hathaway is a female Steve Jobs: precise, wealthy through her own merits and workaholic. She is also quite opposed to boys business club masculinity. But still once she gets DeNiro as an intern she is all about leaning on him as a father figure and an emblem of the father-knows-best men of yore (who knows, for instance that she needs to eat when she doesn't, or that she had too much to drink or knows both on-line advertising/sales AND the streets of Brooklyn better etc.). DeNiro is the opposite of a manic pixie dream girl, he is a Calm Progressive Dream Grandpa, the intangible but eminently crush-able strong, supportive man that checks all the boxes. Fortunately, unless you're a critical asshole, this is all not extremely noticeable, because the leads have mad chemistry together. DeNiro is enjoyable, believable and likeable for the first time in ages and Hathaway is... well great. She cranks it up to 100 and creates a complex character in work and family life and jives stunnigly well with DeNiro's respectful, helpful grandpa. The supporting cast of ditzy hipsters is these for a couple of laughs including a rather cringeworthy 'heist' scene that seemed tacked on. But then again, with the exception of Something's gotta give (and even there the humour wobbles) director meyers never could do comedy and was over and over saved by the strength of the cast. Except in What women want cause fuck that movie. So, yeah, the Intern is appealing and endearing, even if it misfires quite a bit. But if you want to see DeNiro in a good role or Hathaway once more, go see it.
10/10 would recommend.
Just excellent all around. The acting was superb, and the story pulled at every emotion a bit. Good show.
This movie was a guilty pleasure for me, I enjoyed it a lot can't deny it!
A perfectly cute, harmless movie. Don't need to see it in theaters, but worth your time to see sometime. Very good cast, and nobody phones it in.

Thanks to the chemistry of the two superstars in The Intern, DeNiro and Hathaway, The Intern is a likable movie. The story itself is flawed, yes, but DeNiro and Hathaway have excellent chemistry and create two great characters. What I enjoy, when films can do it right, is when there's no "villain." There are flawed people through the movie so writer Nancy Meyers is able to create dilemma, but nobody is a "bad guy." Her films are like this and she's mostly successful. Any movie like this is going to have a problem if the run-time is over 2-hours (The Intern is 2:01). There's just no need for it. Also, the awkward way the The Intern had Jules (Hathaway) deal with Ben (DeNiro) was a snag in the movie. The errors in the story are ones I wouldn't expect from a writer/director of Nancy Meyers' calibre. Once this clumsy part to the story is past, The Intern really takes off. With an 80% audience score, which is excellent, I'd say The Intern is definitely worth a rent.
This is a great movie. It shows the stress of work and family while remaining positive. Great movie.
Very enjoyable film. Far exceeded my expectations. Sad in places, but funny and feel good mostly
Loved the movie. Loved the actors.
A nice feel good movie where you don't have to think that hard... just lose yourself in the idea of human relativity.
Lovely enjoyable feel good film.

I gave it 5 stars because never once did the thought "okay, when will it end" come to mind as it usually does if the film drags... Also it had a nice story to it, if there were cliches I did not notice, because the film had my full attention. Decent actors, funny, heart warming, and it sends a good message. I will be watching it again when it comes out on dvd for sure.

The Intern is directed and written by Nancy Meyers, and it stars Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway in a comedy film about Ben Whittaker (Robert De Niro) who's a senior and wants to apply for a job. So when he come across a program that seniors would become interns from a fashion company, he wants to apply for it, got the job, and now work as an intern for the CEO of About the Fit. It has been a while since I've watched a Nancy Meyers film, and when I saw this film on HBO, I thought, why not, and just record it so I can watch it later. What I didn't realize is that I didn't expect this movie to be really great, just thought it was just there. Robert De Niro is terrific in this, probably his best in a long time as I haven't seen this type of character that he plays before, and he does it pretty well. Anne Hathaway does a good job of the character that she plays, and the chemistry between them is actually the best part of the film as they are pretty much having a friendship with no hints of of a romance, which I'm glad they didn't do that. The writing by Nancy Meyers is pretty interesting in a way that I'm invested in the characters who are developed enough for me to find them likable and memorable. There were some parts that I was worried that it was going to be a big deal, but it goes by short and sweet, which I was relieved and I liked how it was handled. It's really funny, and the drama moments work really well. There were some plot elements that really did not need to be there, even if it is hilarious, and there were some predictable moments in there. But with all of that said, I clearly underestimate The Intern, and I'm glad that I did.
One of my favorite Robert Deniro movies.

Old interns...hmmm haven't heard of this, but I guess it's happening. This is the premise for The Intern and it's not a horrible one. In fact the first half of this movie has a few decent laughs in it. However, the movie takes a turn from hey this old guy is working in a workplace that he's not used to, to old guy and young business owner having a relationship that you aren't sure where it's going. Movies that you know what is going to happen, and what is going to be said but take forever in saying that can be frustrating and that's a little of what is happening here. De Niro is solid here, Hathaway isn't horrible, her husband in the movie is way out of place. He might as well walk around with a sign that says I'm a douche bag. Save this one for the cheap theater.

It's not a good movie... and yet I had to give it a positive ranking because the characterization and conclusions the film makes are inherently different than films of this type. It had me thinking about the conversations and themes and what exactly the film was saying.... and that's better than most films of this genre.

This movie is so charming and heartwarming, Robert De Niro delivers his best work since Silver Lining Play Book and Anne Hathaway also does very well and alongside a decent cast and a very simple but good plot they are all delivering the goods in a very good movie, It's really recomended, especially if you want to feel good...:)

The films deftly plays with inter-generational differences in work and family relationships, while showing how each generation benefits each other. Lo rescatable es quizá el primer tercio de la película, en donde se ve un inicio bien definido donde se construye una linda historia de amistad que se desvía de su camino para ser únicamente salvada por las actuaciones de Robert De Niro y Anne Hathaway.

DeNiro is the only bright star in this thing. The plot is predictable. A slap-stick break-in scene in the middle is entirely out of place and does not contribute to the movie. And the ending is sudden, bland and more befitting an after school special.

Not to confuse with 2013 Fox's The Internship, this similar type of drama without a ship behind feels more promising, funny but not ridiculous and thoughtful which one could have expected through its poster. The story delivers something fresh, a creative idea of senior citizen internship program to present the cross-generation relationship, events that are commonly occur in daily working life and how important is the experience of the elderly to inspire the younger generation. The film moves in a smooth pace, filled with nice musics and inspiring scores, along with a gentle spirit that attracts audiences to spend time following the amusing characters for about 120 minutes but a little bit upset by the rushing second half and too unrealistic perfection on its ending. However, the warm, charming and charismatic chemistry between De Niro and Hathaway is the sweetest and most beautiful part of the film to enjoy which makes us believe that we can manage well both career and family life.

We greatly enjoyed this movie. The chemistry between De Niro and Hathaway was excellent, and it was a pleasure to see a movie that developed a great plot without violence! Many minor characters were also well developed. Interesting premise that developed well throughout the movie. Highly recommend!
Nice!! Light hearted! Enjoyed the movie!!:))
Not the greatest movie but still enjoyable.
De Niro and Hathaway were so believable and adorable in their respective roles. I definitely recommend this movie when you need a mood lifter and/or encouragement. I hope I'm that put-together at 70!

Sorprendentemente entretenida, y lo mejor es que Robert De Niro vuelve a actuar, lease, no esta en automatico con en los ultimos 15 anos (salvo dos o tres excepciones). It recycles familiar stereotypes and cliches that you'd expect from a movie of this genre, meaning the little personality the film has all comes from its admittedly damn solid cast. That and while I admire what was attempted with certain plot points and themes, the film's ending doesn't tie up all the loose ends nearly as neatly as it seems to think it does. 6,5/10
Excellent picturisation of a retired man filling the gaps in his life.
Amazing just goes to show how even though old with experience. Can truly show younger people how to do it. Even though disrespect to the older people still is rife. Really funny and well acted movie!

Sometimes you just have to pay the bills movies are some of my favorites. I love it when great actors make silly movies about love, family and dates strictly for the paycheck. Because they are good actors, the films are typically better than average, they are professionally made and for better or worse hit the spot without making you think or making you more stupid. The Intern is a movie about stereotypes. Old people, young people, startups, New York, business etc etc etc...You can find every single cliche in this 2 hours comedy. I don't know if anyone should skip work to watch this movie, if you have a date or want to have a good time, just go. It's not embarrassing.

Suprisingly excellent and hearfelt. The seamlessly ingenius filmaking that makes you feel like a first person experiencing what the two lead actors/actress are experiencing, is sheer genius! Fantastic film!

Cause I haven't seen him not being grumpy, unfriendly and mean on screen for quite a long time. And I keep thinking that his role would go to Robin Williams if he is still alive. Also, Anne Hathaway looks so "Julia Roberts".

This is a charming movie with some tender moments and some witty humour at times. The story affirms and celebrates values of decency and good manners along with the contribution that older people can make to society. Anne Hathaway has real screen presence as the young CEO who has to overcome her prejudices of having an older intern. It's also good that Robert de Niro is back on screen in a decent role. While the direction loses its focus occasionally, this is an enjoyable, easy-to-watch comedy with some gentle critique of aspects of modern society and good chemistry between its lead actors.
A nice feel good film.
I love how this movie made the classy old school way of doing things cool again.

"The Intern" is a sure-fire hit for adults of all ages. Offering plenty of laughs and smiles, the film tosses in several heavy doses of reality and sadness-all mixed into an otherwise straight-forward storyline. De Niro brings the calmness and demeanor of a James Bond around an office water cooler. His charisma and gentle manners takes us back to a slower, more enjoyable life and pace that can still work in today's nonstop world. The always delightful Hathaway captivates us with her wide-range of acting tools. Together, the team of Hathaway and De Niro combine to give audiences an extremely enjoyable and warm big-screen experience. Grade: A Read my entire movie review at www.reelbrief.com
Decent, harmless, riskless, and therefore forgettable. There's nothing really bad about it, I guess. But it just doesn't have enough there for me to remember.
laughed, cried, worried, cleaver, loved it.

I really enjoyed this movie. Just entertainment, no big messages other than respecting your elders can be a good thing and mutual communication and respect between Millenials and boomers should be valued.
Funny, heart warming and thought provoking. Well worth the cost of the ticket.

I took a date and we both loved it. Thought it would have been more of a comedy but it turned into a comedy with a love story and a little bit of a tear jerker at the end. We would both watch it again.
Feel good movie you can't help but smile.
No surprise plot twists or suspense, but an enjoyable movie about an older man able to befriend and mentor the young people in the company.

De Niro is ace while Anne is not far behind in this positive story of women power n balancing relationships. The edit could have been crisper n sprinkled with more laughs in the script but overall the film does entertain.

Rating: Fine I know sometimes the word fine has a negative connotation, but this is definitely the real definition: "choice, excellent, or admirable". I really enjoyed this movie from beginning to end with only some slight missteps along the way. The strongest aspect of this film is the reality of it. Throughout the story I felt that this characters will part of the real world. And when you believe that the premise behind the movie becomes the clear focus and provides great insight to society while telling an engaging story. The difference between the older generation of Robert De Niro and the younger workforce led by Anne Hatheway introduces just enough to make you question the modern day. While mentioning the actors we can applaud them because they did a wonderful job of getting us to care about the characters, it is nice to see De Niro throwing himself into a role, even if the character is mostly laid-back yet still charming. And of course Anne Hatheway remains to be one of the best actresses out there, and stunningly gorgeous. The movie is not without faults when it attempts to juggle a few too many story-lines and characters that do not always follow through to a satisfying conclusion. In the same vein some of those pieces mismatch the genuine lived in feel and just stand out as silly moments. Still this is an enjoyable tale and y'all should definitely check it out if the premise looks intriguing to you.

Myers tells good stories especially about baby boomers and this is one of her better films due to the unexpected chemistry between Deniro and Hathaway! DeNiro is very touching and believable as a man past his prime trying to prove he still has worth and Hathaway is very believable as a Career Driven working mom who wants it all. Russo is also quite good as DeNiro's potential love interest. Myers does include one plot mechanism that threatens to derail the movie but she recovers. A good date movie! 10-04-2015

Last night we went out with some friends to see, "The Intern". I know the reviews were mixed on this one, but this was the movie we all agreed on and I'm glad we did.*** Robert De Niro was perfect for this part. I advise that you see it! Another new little gem from director Nancy Meyers who has successfully made a modern buddy film with the most unlikely of characters. The story of 70 year old Ben Whitaker taking an opportunity as an intern to a clothing web company helmed by Anne Hathaway. Filled with great moments & characters & filled with a lot of truth. Filled with some delightful moments & was so nice to see De Niro play the lovable character. It's a charming film that isn't hard to fall in love with quickly. In a sea of black films these days it's a rare treat to get a good old fashioned nice film.
Great movie! Great moral values! Rarely does Hollywood actually makes movies like this anymore without sex scenes and vulgarity.

This movie confirmed my opinion that critics see too many movies for different reasons than the rest of us. People like it a lot more than critics do. It is funny, heart-warming and reminds me of several places I worked where I was the only mature person in the building. I spend $x for 90 minutes of entertainment. I'm okay with that - it seems like a fair deal. Robert DeNiro is a charming old world gentleman and Ann Hathaway is the tech exec totally unprepared for her own success. The chemistry works.

It's really not much of a movie. It's fluff. Major fluff. But the legend himself, Robert De Niro, all geared up to play for humor and heart, is at his most charming and beguiling. De Niro is Ben Whittaker, 70, a retired widower hired as an intern for a Brooklyn e-commerce fashion house run by Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway), a work-obsessed wife and mother who can't even think of what she could learn from an old guy until, well, she does. Writer-director Nancy Meyers (Something's Gotta Give, It's Complicated) and De Niro make it all go down way easy.
This is an easy movie to like - what's not to, with DeNiro (self deprecating humor) and Hathaway (strong yet vulnerable) as the leads. Charming but not overly impressive in terms of dramatic range.
Loved it!!!...great feel good movie...Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway are great together...excellent :)
"Smooth & Cheerful ".

Fabulous, perfectly cast, funny, touching film about a 70 year old intern (DeNiro) at a fast rising ecommerce company and the frazzled young ceo (Anne Hathaway) who he befriends and mentors. Very poignant.
I liked this movie a lot!

A movie so devoid of conflict (an email must be deleted! a cashmere sweater arrives askew!) does not have the right to be so darn charming but somehow DeNiiro, Hathaway and company pull off an often sweet and wise workplace comedy. Besides the wonderful supporting cast, the ultra-crisp set design and cinematography make this Brooklyn warehouse a place anyone would want to work for free.
My friend and I went to watch it just a few hours ago and we enjoyed the movie, it was funny, sad and more. I would watch it again

The Intern: A Perfectly Heartwarming film, and much much more! 'The Intern' is run-of-the-mill heartwarming drama about a woman who makes good with an idea, a laptop, and a chair. It's the American Dream, you know.??Through a set of convoluted occurrences, the boss of an internet shopping company, thirty something Jules, takes on "senior interns" (people over 65) to work in her company. That leads to a series of 'surprises.' One surprise is that the old intern 'Ben' (De Niro) is not incompetent. Shocking! They learn that old people have something to contribute. How heartwarming! And the audience is shocked to learn that young folks don't have all the answers. Ben is so willing to help, you wonder where he has been all your life. All the heartwarming drama nearly gave me a heart attack. Suffice to say, it's predictable. The film's efforts to tell a unique story fall flat. It is apparent that this is a star vehicle with a goal of making bank on the combination of De Niro and Hathaway on the screen. It doesn't bomb because of the expertise of the two stars, but the plot drags it down. Ben, a goodhearted seventy-year-old retired divorcee, teaches the youngsters in the office new tricks. He effortlessly makes friends of everyone in Jules' office and knows exactly what everyone needs. He is the perfect intern. At one point of the movie, Jules (Hathaway) asks Ben (De Niro), "Why do you always say the perfect thing?" Why, indeed. He's too perfect and he brings no conflict to the table; in fact, he's boring. Sure, his homespun logic and chill advice are clever, and it is too obvious. But it is heartwarming. The overworked self-made women (Jules) doesn't have time for anyone, especially herself, as she tries to keep her company running. But she's a loving and patient woman who adores her daughter, Paige. Her husband is the 'stay at home dad of the year.' Even when things go awry in their marriage, it's so damn heartwarming that it makes angels vomit. Age barriers are overcome through clever, pat answers. A whiter-than-white cast stand insulated in a web of banal first-world problems. The major conflict in the film comes down to control and self actualization. Sure, in the context of Jules' life, it's important. For a movie, it's not terribly compelling. I'm surprised the film turned out as entertaining as it did. It helps that they didn't throw in a last minute cancer, house burning down or earthquake. That is the rankest type of plot device and I am happy that I haven't seen that in recent dramas and romances. In the film, it's all upper middle-class white America all the time, as if we were in the 50s, Leave it to Beaver version of Brooklyn, NY. I haven't seen a film this white since 'Boyhood.' Then again, an online vendor that sells clothing to "housewives" might attract mainly white college educated employees. Moreover, the film has to ignore class conflict in the 21st century in order to make Jules' problems at all dramatic. In the context of the world, her issues are trite and she is a pathetic whiner, type A personality who thinks her life amounts to a hill of beans in this crazy world. ??Overall, it's handled by the actors: Rental For all the blandness, the two stars pull of a decently entertaining film. But there is no reason to see it in the theater. Peace, Tex Shelters
Very refreshing film. Very good story , not your typical cookie cutter comedy. This was really enjoyable. Well worth seeing for some laughs , a good hearted fun movie.

Despite Deniro's best efforts this movie is a bore fest . Story line could have developed into the old man intern turns out to save the company , instead goes into a sappy "my husband is cheating on me" of characters no one actually cares about. The laughs were far and few in between,.

Acting is good of course especially with those great actors. The movie was fairly long... about two hours but it was never boring. It was just a very cute and feel good movie. Big Nancy Meyers fan? I am but out of all the projects I've seen of hers, this is the weakest one. Though not a bad film, had a lot of flaws particularly the writing, though it is filled with a lot of laugh out loud moments, and good emotional, intense moments. The main reason to see the film is the brilliant believable performance of Robert De Niro. He charms the screen in his role as a senior intern working for the younger generation star Anne Hathaway. Like De Niro, Anne Hathaway is also very loving, funny, believable, and is someone you can't take your eyes off. The two of them give it their all and have marvelous work/friendship chemistry together. The supporting cast is good for the most part but very underused, particularly Renee Russo. There are so many better ways the story could've gone, but this is not a very strong story. Overall though, very entertaining with much praise to the two leads. My grade=81%(B-).

The Intern is evidence that movies can comedies can be uplifting, entertaining and sophisticated without crude humour and corny moments. Strong leads from both De Niro and Hathaway together with other very solid and likeable characters meant that this was a very enjoyable movie. The story is grown up and simple. The laughs are gentle and subtle but it leaves you feeling happy. Its a formula which has been tested before at silly humour level but this story is very realistic and bright. It was lovely to see a film without a mean bone in its body. The plot relentlessly refuses to go to obvious places and treats all of its leads and even minor characters with respect. The film suffers mildly from having no villain or major conflict, but makes up for it with the charming interplay between DeNiro and Hathaway, who have cut crisp corners on each of their character's back stories, giving us three dimensional people whom we legitimately care about and want to see them succeed.

VIEWS ON FILM review by Jesse Burleson 2015's The Intern (my latest review) is great. There I said it. This is feel-good, cotton candy people. You stagger out of the theater with a sense of giddiness. Then you say to yourself, "wow, that's a real film". Its lead (Mr. Robert De Niro) has never been more likable. You wouldn't even know it's the same guy who played psychotics (Taxi Driver, Cape Fear), hardened criminals (Heat, The Family), and ornery grandpappys (Meet the Fockers, Little Fockers) some years ago. Crazy. With his co- star being Anne Hathaway (also very likable), screen chemistry is indeed abounding. A friendship develops between their characters producing an inner wallop. Now in all honesty, I don't ever cry at the movies. Here, I got the sniffles and that's saying something. As directed by Nancy Meyers, "Intern" has one of her trademarks written all over it. That would be the adage of well-off people having problems (in relationships) that aren't life-threatening. You could also include the notion of two protagonists sharing scenes and being worlds apart in age (remember Keanu Reeves and Diane Keaton in Something's Gotta Give?). So yeah this flick is cutesy at times. Yeah it ends with a level of uncertainty (talking about cinema makes way for interpretation you know). Yeah it starts off sort of predictable. Yeah it has some nitwit, supporting characters and yes, there's a cringe-worthy boner gag (don't ask). But look closer and stick around for the full two hours (despite what other critics thought, the overlength didn't bother me). There's something deeper than what was advertised in the trailer. Here's a hint and spoiler alert (warning): The husband of Hathaway's persona (Matt Ostin played by Anders Holm), isn't much of a shade and doesn't hold the screen until his revelatory stance hits you up in the third act. Talk about a plot diversion in a so-called, mawkish comedy. Shot near the perky side of Brooklyn, New York and featuring an email heist referencing caricatures from Ocean's Eleven, The Intern is a romcom without the "rom", a centerpiece sledgehammering facets of old age (you could also throw in older people's spar with newer technology). The story starts off without a struggle or conflict before later kicking into high gear. You have Ben Whittaker (De Niro), a widower who just wants some higher form of human interaction. He's retired, he's traveled the world, he hangs out at Starbucks, and when walking down the street, he gets hit on by weird women (Linda Lavin from the TV show Alice, who'd thunk it). Sadly, this is not enough for him. The solution: He signs up for a community outreach program in which seniors intern for thirtysomething boss, Jules Ostin (Hathaway). Ostin owns a Internet fashion company, built from the ground up. She's initially reserved, conservative, and off-putting. And her first impression of Ben is that he's too observant not to mention a little invading. Then things change. As time marches on, De Niro's Ben and Hathaway's Jules form a wonderful kinship. They eventually turn into best friends. Refreshingly, it was great to see two Oscar winners thrive at the top of their game. When they're on screen (together or separate), "Intern" is a real winner. When they aren't in frame (which hardly ever happens), the material is sadly, a little sluggish and kind of hackneyed. Anyway, if you've recently watched The Internship (2013), you'll somewhat be reminded of The Intern. Both films start off similar yet the latter ascends to something much greater. Bottom line: Chalk up another round of effective, sentimental goo courtesy of the veritable Nancy Meyers. I'm gonna go with a rating of 3 and a half stars on this one. Of note: De Niro's Ben Whitaker has a need to fill a void in his life. He's retired with money yet is bored. That's why he takes on the task of working in e-commerce territory. De Niro the actor, well he seems to be filling that same void (Bobby's rich but still likes to appear in three to four movies a year). With endeavors like Grudge Match, Last Vegas, New Year's Eve, and 2013's Killing Season, he hasn't been too picky about his projects. The Intern thankfully, reverses this trend. Mucho "De Niro" justified!
Sweet movie... I was happy to see Rene in the movie too.

who says you can't teach an old dog new tricks? follow the life of a business man, and widower, as he struggles to find his place in life after retirement. i really enjoyed the love-hate, father/daughter type chemistry between Jules and Ben, as they try and better each other's lives one awkward situation at a time. some parts were cheesy, and some parts probably could have been added, or left out, but overall the movie comes together nicely. i recommend this movie if you need a heart warming, fun loving, comedy, or if you just love any of the actors, because they were all pretty good, even the unneeded fillers!
