Despite having a knack to make charming romcoms, Meyers self-sabotages her premise. The Intern is about fitting in with the times while maintaining a certain humbleness before those who have what is irreplaceable: life experience. While the film is a glimpse into 90s Hollywood in modern cinema - and some of the good that came with it - it also shows that the cinematic language has evolved but Myers didn't.

The Intern is one of the best rom com style movie that I've seen in awhile, even though there isn't much romance between our main characters other than a father daughter relationship. This movie is simple but it's effective in everything it tries to do, and may even have an underlying message about how we see women is the work place and in society.

The Intern is directed by Nancy Meyers and stars the great Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway. This is the first Nancy Meyers film I am seeing and I was pleasantly surprised with how much I enjoyed the intern. The Intern is a sweet feel good comedy that starts off as a movie showcasing the differences in lifestyle,mannerisms and characteristics between the current generation and the older generation before heading towards the more drama heavy side of things with De Niro guiding Anne Hathaway in some of her life choices. De Niro is fantastic in this film and his character is so likeable. Anne Hathaway is great as well and the chemistry between the two is the main reason why this movie is so damn entertaining. De Niro's interactions with some of the other younger interns are also hilarious and had the audience laughing out loud. My only issue with the intern is that there are some unnecessary scenes which don't really add much to the movie and hamper the pace making it feel slightly long. The Intern is definitely worth watching when you are in the mood for something light hearted. B
Hilarious, I laughed HARD multiple times. Great mix of emotions felt in this movie. Good movie for a date and or with a few buddies.

Out of the long list of films I had planned to go and see, The Intern was nowhere close to being on that list, but when my girlfriend felt the need to tag along to the movies with me and adamantly suggested that we take a break from the norm and try one of "her movies", I went against my better judgment and begrudgingly agreed, little did I know she would choose a film that was finally watchable. I say watchable because this movie is basically a sequel to The Devil Wears Prada but without Meryl Streep, but instead plugging Robert De Niro in the Anne Hathaway role and allowing Hathaway to play the Miranda role without the attitude and confrontation, thus making this movie a boring heartwarming work place character piece without the drama. This film comes across as just a movie to fill a slot during a slow weekend where no prominent films that people take seriously were debuting. The pacing is slow and the characters are bland to the point that you don't care about whatever benign conflict that they try to interject into the plot to give the story purpose and I was just hoping that the movie would hurry up and reach its obvious conclusion so I could leave. The casting was about the only thing that they got right with this movie. The plot was basically a mash up of The Internship and The Devil Wears Prada but without the witty one liners or eccentric bosses which leaves you wondering what's the point. At best this is about on par with a made for tv Lifetime movie which pretty much means I am not in the demographic that this movie was trying to target, but if your into that very mellow drama kind of films then I would say it is better than most and worth you checking out

A Nancy Meyers film has no place for gritty realism so with that in mind, this is a safe and nice film that's slightly overlong, oftentimes sitcom-y and does exactly what it says on the tin. Lack of surprises aside, De Niro and Hathaway gave it their best to give the flimsy material some weight and drama in the third act but it was never meant to be. The takeaway here is that the technology obsessed youths can learn a few things from seniors who've got the experience of life. How delightful but hardly profound! The script could've been written by your hip grandma who has managed to master whatsapp - give it an extra star rating if you are into that sort of escapist nonsense.

This movie has been promoted as a comedy but its really little more that a 'chick flick' designed to propagate the idea that 'you can have it all'. Jules has a successful startup company, a loving and supportive husband and a beautiful daughter but her commitment to her career results in problems at home. The company decided to develop a 'Senior Intern' who, over time, becomes like a father to her. With the wisdom of Solomon he guides her through various problems. In true Hollywood fashion this 70 year old middle-class guy just happens to have spent his career as VP of publishing company (don't all middle class people retire from upper level management?). When the problems at home begin to take its toll he, in true feminist fashion, convinces here that even though she has little time for her family its not her fault and that she needs to be "true to herself". I guess that means she should put herself ahead of her family and others. Overall, a 'feel good' movie with good acting and a story line that does entertain. Were it not for the obvious sexist theme and absurd message I might rate it higher but because of its heavy political nature I can only rate it 2 stars

"The Intern" is a film starring Robert DeNiro who enters a senior citizen internship program to bring a new dynamic to Anne Hathaway's start-up telecommunications firm. At first, Hathaway has a hard time warming up to DeNiro but comes to form an affecting, unlikely bond with him. This film is watchable, but I wasn't sold on the whole new-age generation gap thing. This film has a lot to say about generation gaps and that older people have to get hip with the current times. While both are highly competent actors, I thought the dynamic was a bit bizarre, and had their ages not been so vastly different, it might have worked. Both do solid acting but it doesn't make the relationship any better. I thought the film was also fleeting and absent a decent score and some interesting dialogue, this film is thoroughly forgettable. It is very whimsical and doesn't tread any new narrative ground not treaded before. This is a film meant for simple viewing without any deeper meaning --------------------------------------------------------------- C+

Slow to start, and largely predictable, but mostly avoids cliches. A mildly interesting premise - what would happen if 70 year old Robert De Niro were working for internet startup entrepreneur Anne Hathaway? At first, very little but the film builds to a nice ending, but with a firm ambition to sell you The Intern 2 too. 61 year old Rene Russo is the love interest for De Niro, The rest of the characaters are not really explored serving variously as foils for De Niro or Hathaway. Some of the plot is implausible - how does De Niro solve an IT problem that the Internet startup boss cannot? Mostly seeing this film reminded me of the character De Niro played in "Once Upon A Time In America", The 70 year old De Niro looks very look the aged gangster Noodles Aaronson . But Nancy Meyers is no Sergio Leone. This is an altogether gentler film, sentimental in parts,

Too entertaining to warrant a senior skip day thanks to its leads, The Intern takes a softball approach to its promising premise but moviegoers can't help but love the chemistry behind this office non-romance. Just like with any other Nancy Meyers comedy, moviegoers get introduced to a work roster of goofy but lovable supporting characters and an overall story that feels fresh despite ultimately plucking the strings of predictability. Oh, some unsuspected roadblocks might surprise you but the final trajectory's always pretty clear. What makes The Intern unique so far as this writer-director's CV goes, however, is the age of the female lead. Her ensemble work aside (The Holiday), Meyers tends to stay within her actual range (Diane Keaton, Something's Gotta Give and It's Complicated). In dotcom founder Jules, however, we get a mega successful glass ceiling-breaking online store founder who's got a family to boot. Far from a caricature, she's also a spread-too-thin boss who invests in a camaraderie and loyalty-building environment for her employees (on-site masseuse, lax dress code, office bike riding), as well as no patience for her mother and not enough time for her hubby. In Anne Hathaway, Meyers finds one of the only actresses capable of coloring in and outside of her lines to a brilliant degree. You come to love Jules, just as you do the title character. Since committing to comedy nearly full time (Analyze This, Meet the Parents), Robert De Niro has gotten warmer and has gotten the audience to warm to him more as an Everyman. Notice that those successful flicks listed in the last sentence don't require much suspension of disbelief for buying the actor outside of his usual tough guy wheelhouse. With The Intern, however, we get a full drawn portrait of a still-vital retiree helping Jules through some crucial work and life changes. Hathaway and De Niro work so well together and their personalities complement so perfectly at this juncture in their lives that you wonder how they would have melded if she got dropped into one of his films during the height of his H'wood run (Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Goodfellas). In this PG-13-rated comedy from writer/director Nancy Meyers (The Parent Trap, What Women Want), a 70-year-old widower (DeNiro) becomes bored with retirement and takes a senior intern position at an online fashion site created and run by a much younger woman (Hathaway). Beyond Hathaway and De Niro's compatibility, however, their remains some problems with this twosome's vehicle. Fluffy is the word for The Intern, which could have made some riper social commentary as to the actual viability of pension-aged Americans in the workplace and old vs. new approaches to business. Oh, Meyers bats around such discussion a bit but she seems to be wearing an oven mitt, only lightly touching on these talking points. Still, even the color-by-numbers moments make for an enjoyable office dynamic. Bottom line: High Pension

I walked into this film with high hopes and walked out angered, angry because I didn't get to see the Robert de Niro I wanted to see. Angry because I know Anne Hathaway is much better than she seemed in this film. Angry because I lived in New York and I know that no one is that freaking happy. Do not waste your money or your time. 1 star.

It helps that the film maintains a light and breezy tone, moves quick from scene to scene and is filled with hilarious one liners. Anne Hathaway and Robert De Niro share brilliant chemistry and deliver fine performances! Among the most "feel-good" movies I've seen in recent times and you're sure to leave the cinema with a smile on your face!

Charming and witty movie that breaks with some conventions that the audience expects to see and thus remains believable. There's no denying the fact that Robert DeNiro had a hell of a time making the movie, he *is* the movie and everybody groups around him. There's also no doubt that he has a wonderful Anne Hathaway at his side who - in my view - excels even in a comedy movie. Yes, you could say at times the movie stretches its believability, esp. when I mention a certain "robbery" - which I could have easily lived without. And yes, the focus changes from De Niro to Hathaway in the course of the movie, but the movie is always charming, witty, and it just reminds you of your parents or grandparents and makes you wonder what live has in store for you. I have enjoyed this movie and rarely have heard so much heartful laughter in an audience. This is a great movie, despite what the critics say. :)

This is a movie of Ben " who is a 70 years old retired " salary-man"and Jules who is a young entrepreneur." Salary-man" is a Japanese word. The salary-man work at a company for 40 years. They are very royal and trustworthy.They wake up very early.They wear always necktie and business suit. They love family. They work till 60 years old. These are typical stereotypes of the Japanese salary man. Robert De Nero played a nice salary man. Arigato. ( Japanese "Thank you"). However, Ben, salaryman is great.After his retirement, he applied for some internship. He was not a good at new technology.But he had wisdom, humbleness and experience. Young workaholic president played by Anne Harthaway was begging to listen to his opinion.Even this salary man got a girl friend. He encouraged the elderly. I really enjoyed salary man's success story. He loves Chinese Tai chi. It makes him healthy. I hope he lives till age of 100 years old.At the end of the movie, Julie joined his Tai Chi lesson.I hope that she enjoy her zen moment! Sayonara( Japanese " Good Bye').

The only way I can possibly explain this low score, is that the critics must have been men. And, lo and behold, most are! This movie covered so many modern-day issues and did it seamlessly; (some but not all) re-entering the work force, accessing technology, and most important, stereotypes and the struggle women in the work force still continue to receive and deal with on a day-to-day basis. This movie was wonderful and everyone should see it, but women most of all should watch this and be inspired that we can still achieve the dream of being equals in the business world and have a family.

I really enjoyed "The Intern," but have a quibble about its treatment of middle aged & senior women. I loved the interaction between DeNiro & the younger men (although he never seemed to get them to want to shave--hey guys ZZ Top is right---every girl is crazy about a sharp-dressed man!) I rated this move 3 1/2 for two reasons: the way older women are depicted (as "raging bitches"--Jules Mom--\ complete buffoons--the intern who couldn't drive--or the pushy, lonely one-night stand--Linda Lavin's character). Older women can also be as suave, well-dressed, & knowledgeable as older men. I'm tired of seeing women my age used as nothing more than comic relief. Having Rene Russo as the sole older woman who is sane doesn't balance out the other 3. I also felt that the movie didn't need a really late (story-wise) plot twist. Overall, an enjoyable movie. DeNiro's performance shows he can do comedy as well as he can do drama & I didn't want to kill Anne Hathaway 5 minutes in, so she did fine too. The young actress playing her daughter is adorable & I would be crushing on the other men in the picture if only they'd shave, tuck in their shirts, & dress sharply.

After reading all of the so-so reviews of this movie, I had gauged my expectations, and was delighted to see a fun, ironic and (at times) a film with deep insightsespecially into what amount to Horatio Alger stories with a woman playing the head of a start-up dot com. The idea that "she can do it all"-- family, mom, wife and company head is not so much challenged (any more than it would be for a man), but placed into focus. In the 1950s-60s, the nose-to-the-grindstone man in the gray flannel suit was seen as a person whose family was ignored at the expense of attention to his family. This film is refreshing in that it recognizes that concentrating on work over family is not a mortal sin and any problems with spouse and child cannot to blamed on the Type A personality in the family regardless of gender. Robert De Niro is perfect. At 70 he is retired and bored, but he doesn't come across either as a fuddy-duddy Luddite or a swinging grandpa. Keeping in mind that the De Niro character was in his 30s when personal computers came on the scene in early 1980s and just 40 when the Mac was released in 1984, computer technology in the home and office is not exactly new. Getting used a new type of interface or program does take time, but it is no longer the mystery box it was at one time to the older generation. This is a much more intelligent (and fun) movie than I expected; so, if you plan to go 1) lower your expectations 2) pay attention, and 3) enjoy!

3.5/5* or 7.5/10 Being a gentleman, having true class, women empowerment, how life doesn't end after a certain age and how to deal with real life relationships are all things a film like The Intern deals with. The Intern is the definition of feel good cinema, I can guarantee you that throughout the film you will be smiling, and there so many instances the film is just so heart touching.But what really works for the film is the lead cast of Robert D'Niro who is only getting better with age, and Anne Hathaway who is epitome of really beauty. There chemistry is just perfect. Story wise the film talks about a 70 year old man named Ben, he is officially retired, and is a widower. After traveling the globe for awhile, he is back home and hates thinking about living at home all day,so he keeps himself busy all the time, sometimes he goes to visit his kids, or goes to starbucks etc. Until one day he learns of a opportunity to become a senior Intern at a online fashion company, and he pounces at the opportunity. He eventually gets the job, and meets the owner of the company Jules. Jules is a young but busy women running a company by herself, and she has a family which her stay at home husband runs. How the not so tech savy senior intern Ben comes into Jules's life and helps her in her journey is what the film is about. Acting wise, I must say Robert D'Niro steals the show, his character is so well written, and he embodies the traits of being a classy gentleman wonderfully. Anne Hathaway looks so beautiful, but more importantly gives a superb,mature act.The rest of supporting cast has done a great job, and is casted perfectly. The Intern is a movie made for a mature audience, and while the film has many laughs, the films undertone meanings are what really win your heart. I truly loved how the film dealt with the message of women empowerment in such a fresh but beautiful way. And one of the films major assets was how the character of Robert D'Niro was written, how even after being 70 he is still enjoying his life to the fullest, and how he is a true gentleman. I mean for me the film really didn't have any negatives other than the place slackened a bit towards the end Overall The Intern is not a pathbreaking film, but the film truly lived up to its amazing trailer.Its nice to see a film deal with real life situations, in a beautiful, light manner and not be so serious and sad. Its a film I throughly enjoyed without any hiccups, and its a film I highly recommend, you get your tickets worth in just seeing the chemistry between D'Niro and Hathaway. 3.5/5* or 7.5/10

+Anne Hathaway glows in "The Intern" whether she is leading 200+ employees of a company she founded or getting drunk and throwing up into a dumpster or crying when she has been betrayed or any of the many emotions she experiences in this 2 hour movie. On the other hand it is time Robert De Niro gave up broad comedies as he is only repeating every movement and mugging face he has made since "Analyze This", "Meet The Parents" and "Meet The Frockers". He has made many comedies throughout his career but for the past decade and a half it seems he wants to be Jerry Lewis! For a comedy "The Intern" is only mildly amusing with the funniest scene having nothing to do with advancing the plot but a 'breaking and entering' mission, which was written, and directed, by Nancy Meyers who has had success with previous films dealing with whether a woman can 'have it all'. Most of the film was made in Brooklyn showing the New York borough as green and sparkling and having an empty parking spot for any in the cast of the film. The various supporting characters from Anders Holm as Hathaway's stay at home husband and dad to their very precocious daughter JoJo Kushner to Rene Russo as a love interest for De Niro--whew! No, not Hathaway! Among young employees in Hathaway's company Peter Vack, Andrew Rannells, Nat Wolff along with Linda Lavin, Zack Pearlman and Christina Holtan and others do what they can with the material given them. "The Intern" is a pleasant movie but drags in spots and touches on subjects without following through such as Hathaway's relationship with her mother. Oh yes I don't ever remember seeing so many pillows on beds, decorative or utilitarian, whether in a home or a hotel!

One of the sweetest movies you may ever see. The Intern exudes charm at every turn and drags you in from the first few scenes. The acting was near perfection and I completely forgot I was watching Anne Hathaway and Robert de Niro almost immediately. The writing was very nearly flawless except for the husband character who needed some work. The film will bring laughs, smiles and may even hit you right in the feels as you sit through a very fast two hour story with a soundtrack that makes you feel incredibly comfortable. The Intern is absolutely one of my top movies of the year.

Sometimes you don't need a film to try and change the world, make bold political or societal statements or even be shocking. Sometimes it's good enough to be an audience member who can just sit back, relax and enjoy the show... and smile. That's the kind of movie you get when you sit down to enjoy "The Intern" (PG-13, 2:01). Robert DeNiro plays the title character, a retired 70 year-old widower who has become bored with his life. After 40 years in the business of printing telephone books and then losing his beloved wife of 42 years, he did his best to adjust to his new life, and it worked - for a while. He traveled the world and engaged in a wide variety of physical and intellectual pursuits to keep himself occupied, but it wasn't enough. When walking the streets of his native Brooklyn, he sees a flyer for a senior intern program at a young, but burgeoning internet clothing company. Ben feels that learning more about technology and working with young people feels like just the challenge he needs to occupy his mind and his time. He applies, via a terrific self-made video (the company's requirement), and sits through a series of amusing interviews with company employees young enough to be his grandchildren... and he gets the internship. Ben ends up working directly for the company's very capable, but over-extended founder, played by Anne Hathaway. The senior intern program was her idea, but Jules is initially hesitant to deal with Ben personally on a daily basis. She's a perfectionist who's constantly on the go. She's difficult to work for and she knows it. She loves and respects all 220 of her employees, but her motto might as well be "If you want something done right, you have to do it yourself." Yet, it's hard to resist Ben's earnestness, strong work ethic and wise, calming presence. After a little awkwardness as Ben and Jules both try to figure out how he can best serve his new boss, he ends up becoming her driver. In this capacity, he gets to know Jules' stay-at-home husband (Anders Holm), their precocious, but adorable young daughter (JoJo Kushner) and, most importantly, Jules herself, in all her earnestness, anxiety and vulnerability. It turns out that, at this stage of the game, Jules needs Ben's wisdom and support more than she'd be willing to admit - to him or herself. Her company is growing so fast and she's so hands-on that one of her assistants (Andrew Rannells) tells her that the investors would like to see her take on a CEO. This would lighten her load, but it would also mean effectively giving control of her company to someone else. She half-heartedly interviews people to be her potential boss, not sure that this is the best move, but wanting to do right by her employees and her marriage, which is starting to suffer due to the demands of her very busy schedule. In the midst of all this, Ben becomes a sounding board and occasional advice dispenser for Jules, a very helpful co-worker and kind of pseudo uncle to a small group of the company's young employees (played by Adam DeVine, Zack Pearlman, Jason Orley and Christina Scherer) and a possible love interest for the company's full-time in-house masseuse (Rene Russo). Ben is at the story's center, but it's the great mix of interesting characters and subplots that makes this movie so worthwhile. DeNiro has rarely been more pleasant to watch, or Hathaway so winning, as they lead an ensemble cast that complements each other wonderfully. Nancy Myers' amusing and purposeful script and direction highlight the virtues of women making the most of their lives, but never hits us over the head with her message. Jules is simply a modern woman who's very likeable and subtly inspiring. A scene in which some of Jules' employees break the law to help her with a pressing personal problem is fun, but seems misplaced, and the resolutions to some of the story's conflicts seem a little trite, but, overall, this is simply a delightful film that I'd recommend to anyone. "The Intern" isn't perfect, but is definitely worth having around. "A-"

The Intern is a simple, predictable movie--an old gentleman who wants a life meets a young person who is lost, and they eventually sort things out with some tears on the side. However, that's one of the major factor that made me like this movie. It's charming, cute, makes you laugh, and these things never get old. I know this might get some criticism for its cheesiness and its simplicity, but it's a good drama movie that makes you smile (probably what it's meant to do) and, honestly, I don't really expect much more in this area. It does its job, most movies fail to do so; maybe not a 'great' movie, but a good one.

Ah, Nancy! For years now (in films like "What Women Want," "The Holiday" and "It's Complicated"), you have been writing and directing films that put women front and center - professional women, with impressive credentials - only to undermine the power of that image with a strange brand of (unintentional?) misogyny. On the surface, your films look, at first, like feminist confections, but then you always end up trafficking in the worst kind of feminine stereotypes. No matter what their strengths and achievements, your protagonists are inevitably emotional, irrational, and in need of a man to make things right. Even a career woman needs love, no matter what the cost, you always remind us. At least in "Something's Gotta Give" - my favorite of yours - you bring the man down a peg as much as the woman. How broadminded of you ... In "The Intern," Meyers turns things around (a bit), taking the perfect man and turning him into good ole Dad - or, at least, a father figure - in the form of Robert De Niro, who once wowed the world with his kinetic energy in films like "Taxi Driver," and now spends his time mugging for the camera in films like "Last Vegas" (and "The Intern"). De Niro plays 70-ish Ben, who was once an executive at a phonebook (remember those?) company and is now a retired widower in need of something to fill his days. When he sees a flyer advertising a "senior intern" program at a local (Brooklyn, NY) e-commerce company, he jumps at the chance to apply, just to have something to do. The movie opens with Ben recording his application video, intercut with a montage of his present-day life, which includes a trip to San Francisco to see his son and grandchildren and, back home, an awkward exchange with a local widow - played by a very funny, if under-utilized, Linda Lavin (of "Alice" fame) - who has her own plan for how to cure Ben's loneliness. Lo and behold, the company - an internet fashion retailer called "About the Fit" - calls Ben in, and he gets the gig. If it all seems a bit easy, it is, helped along by the usual easy-listening soundtrack of composer Theodore Shapiro ("We're the Millers"). Still, De Niro, hamminess aside, is pleasant enough to watch, and there are a few gags that score. So what is a "senior intern" to do? Well, no one knows, really, least of all the founder and CEO of the company, 30-ish Jules - played by Anne Hathaway ("Interstellar") with her usual spunk - but Ben is assigned to her, anyway. She ignores him, until Ben makes himself so indispensable to the entire office (he's that just that kind of guy) that she just has to take notice, and before long he is driving her to and from work, watching her kid, and spending time in her (amazing) Brooklyn brownstone with house-husband (sorry, "stay-at-home dad," as Jules corrects Ben) Matt - a very forgettable Anders Holm ("Unexpected"). And why does Jules - successful internet mogul that she is - need and respond to this new older masculine presence? Well, it turns out that all is not perfect at home or at work: she never sees hubby, and when she does, they're both too tired to talk or get it on; she can't spend even the minimal time with her daughter that she should; and her investors think she should take on a "real" (male) CEO to allow her to work less and focus on the company's vision. Since what we see on the screen kind of supports these facts and assessments of her performance (maybe not the male CEO part), it's hard not to agree that, yes, she needs help. And with Ben so competent, he's just the fellow to save the day. It's all relatively harmless, and occasionally touching and funny, but all to often it's just a little regressive for my taste. Ben even finds a more appropriate - for Meyers' taste - love interest in the form of the beautiful office masseuse played by Rene Russo (Nightcrawler), charming as ever, and, of course, 11 years younger than Ben (Lavin's character is just too old and pushy). If the film were 30 minutes shorter and with all of the exposition cut out - Ben to Jules, "You can do it on your own" - it might be more watchable and I might forgive it its faults in the breezy rush to the finish line. But so often, it's a bit of a slog. Then again, if you've loved every other Nancy Meyers film, then you might be used to her aesthetic and not mind any of it. If so, then go see it in the full confidence that the director is true to her own legacy.

The Guardian's Jordan Hoffman writes that The Intern is a "chain of predictable sequences shot in a flat manner." THIS IS THE INTERN WE ARE TALKING ABOUT HERE. Stop trying to over analyze it and just enjoy it for what it is: enjoyable.

Father of the Bride 1 & 2, The Parent Trap, What Woman Want and Something's Gotta Give. Some of my favorite feel-good/rom-com films from the past. They all have one thing in common, they're directed by the great Nancy Meyers. Meyers is one of the director's that every time she releases a film I'm always super excited to check it out because it could become a Nancy Meyers classic like the films listed above. Is this a Nancy Meyers classic? Yes and No. First off I must start by saying I enjoyed this film. It's a funny, charming and breezy. The performances by De Niro, Hathaway and Rene Russo are great, and kudos to Meyers for bringing out a solid performance out of De Niro that shows that he can still be great when he tries. The film also looks nice and boasts a fun score that's straight out of the '90s. It was heartfelt, inspiring and surprising at times and then at other times the film gets lost tonally and suffers "at times" because of it. There's something so great about seeing a film that has a strong female lead and showcases female empowerment in such an honest and relatable way. Also a film that shows that no matter your age you never lose your value. Even though the film veers off its familiar but enjoyable path from time-to-time, and I'm sorry Workaholics fans but Anders Holm was so miscast and delivered the worst performance I've probably seen all year. And also the ending is so abrupt and story lines are left in limbo and never wrapped up. SO, besides a few glaring negatives and some major and minor bumps in the road this is still an enjoyable at times and I can see certain audience members being very moved and uplifted by it especially if they can relate to the characters. Also, the film introduces JoJo Kushner in her first ever theatrical movie role and she just might be the cutest child actor ever that had great chemistry and line delivery, I'm sure we'll be seeing more from her in the future. Overall, I'll just barely give THE INTERN a 6 out of 10. It's a decent matinee film and if you're a Nancy Meyers fan there will be enough familiarity there to enjoy. Just don't pay too much for it and expect a Nancy Meyers classic and you'll be film.

This is mostly harmless, emphasis on that first word. This is a typical Nancy Meyers film. Basic plot you can probably guess from the trailer: DeNiro comes in on the plot contrivance of an older intern program, and ends up helping Hatheway overcome her stress from running her company and trying to maintain her family life with a stay-at-home dad, with the main conflict being whether or not she'll hire an experienced CEO to help run the company. What follows is often amusing albeit a pretty standard plot, which is reasonably well acted, and charming enough that you can probably tell if you'll like the movie just from the trailer. Now, about that emphasis: two elements of this film made me cringe, and I'm not talking about the occasional joke that didn't work for me. The first is that at one point DeNiro and some of the other interns commit a felony, with Hatheway's knowledge and endorsement, in order to save her some embarrassment from her mother. Is this supposed to show she's competent at running her company? The mother character is completely superfluous to the plot; she's only there to be a nag on the phone, is never seen, and could have easily been written out of the plot. The second I won't get into too much detail about, but suffice to say it's presented as being empowering to Hatheway but instead came off, to me, as trite, cliche, and disempowering and playing to stereotypes. In other words: typical Nancy Meyers. Ugh. If that bothers you less than me, then you may have fun with this. Personally, those bits that bothered me could have been cut or reshaped, giving a shorter runtime (2 hours is pushing it for what is essentially a comedy), leading to a slightly above middling score.

When I first heard about this concept, I was intreged and when I watched the first trailer, I was actually excited to see this film. When I got a chance to go and watch the movie four days before it came out, I jumped at the chance and I'm glad I did. This film was so charming. It shows that even though they may be a difference in generation, there are some things that we can relate to, young and old. It had comedic moments which was great and Robert De Niro's character is so likeable. What I loved the most about this movie is how a women is portrayed. With films such as Suffurgettes and the last Hunger Games coming out, we need more movies about powerful women. Anne Hataways character always talks about how hard it is to be a women in the business world. People don't take you or your job too seriously. They also think that women can't run a business. This is something that is very important for me. I always try to break that stereotype and do something that I love whilst not letting my gender define me. It's hard at times but I get by. I love that De Niro's characters doesn't care about gender as well. He always cares about the personally. If the person has the passion or not and if they are good at what they do. Sometimes, the things that Hathaway's character does have some consequences and can make others insecure which is why she has a great partner in the senior intern. He advices her on the personal life while she helps in the business and technology life. In the end, I enjoyed it.

I saw The Intern in avant-premiere at the Ostend Movie Festival in Belgium. Anne Hathaway is a successful entrepreneur of an e-commerce fashion shop. Her husband takes care of housekeeping and their child and only gets to see her tired late at night. Meanwhile De Niro gets hired as a senior trainee at Hathaway's company and offers moral support when Hathaways husband is having an affair. Although The Intern offers a few good laughs and both De Niro and Hathaway give good acting performances, this is not the good tragic comedy drama it could have been. The Intern resigns to a simple moral tale: in the movie the husband is the 'bad guy' for having an affair and Hathaway the hero. Fact is in real life, both are victims of a very competitive society which means in order to be very successful, it often means one needs to neglect one's family. The Intern tries to be feministic, but in fact Hathaway in order to run her company neglects her husband and child (something men have often been accused for in the last decades). In stead of using this situation to discuss the impact of having a demanding career on family life, The Intern ends up being a simple good-bad tale. Never the less The Intern offers nice and easy accessible entertainment in typical Hollywood fashion. But it's depth is neglectable.

A ladies-friendly and gentle comedy, The Intern is a predictable, unrealistic and overly sentimental delivery which hugely, if not mostly, relies on the presence of its two leading characters. A so-so melodramatic, feministic story is told in a way which would neither annoy you, nor amaze you, but it would just work fine for a calm lazy evening with your beloved half during the cold winter. Ben Whittaker (Robert De Niro) is a retired successful businessman who cannot simply enjoy the calm life of being a pensioner and decides to participate in a senior-intern program. Soon gets assigned to be the assistant to a young founder (Anne Hathaway) of a super successful start-up in the field of online sales. Slowly, both of them have to learn how to work together, but also to learn to be different persons. Needless to say, the level of predictability, the lack of any climax in the story development and the completely unrealistic depiction of what the post-modern start-up corporate world is, damage the movie's chances to be taken seriously. Luckily for director Nancy Meyers, the presence of Anne Hathaway and Robert De Niro and the formidable chemistry between them somehow saves the movie from being a complete flop and actually turns it into something passable. As a whole, The Intern could have been a much better movie, given the record of Nancy Meyers (Something's Gotta Give), but in the end the flaws in her overall approach towards the story is partially compensated by the actors and the feel good final feeling. Watchable during a flight or in a cold winter evening with your better half next to you.

THE INTERN Review The Intern is a comedy that everyone can enjoy. It features refreshingly likeable characters, a charming story, and a lot of gut-busting humor. This movie is a story of a fish out of water story, of friendship, relationships, working in business, and the challenges and advantages that the classic "age gap" presents. Strangely, the movie feels like it would be a dime-a-dozen romantic comedy if the two characters were closer in age. But this is just one way that this film feels fresh as the plot, characters, and situations don't feel overly forced. There is a mix of old and new that works well here because, as we know, experience never gets old. In modern Brooklyn Robert De Niro stars as Ben Whitaker who, as a 70 year old widower, chooses in his retirement to work as an intern for Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway) the multitasking founder of a growing internet clothing trying to have success in business and family life. Over time they come to see each others value more. Both of the leads are delightfully likable characters and you want them to reach their goals. Ben's chivalrous and experienced attitude makes him the epitome of the title "oldie but goodie". Jules is a representation of the new age entrepreneurial business kickstarters who are admired today. The differences between these two is never uncomfortable and keep the audience hoping to see more of what these two will accomplish. All of the supporting cast are also interesting and play off of each other remarkably well. These include Rene Russo (Thor) as the flirtatious maseus, Nat Wolff (Paper Towns) as a manager, Adam Devine (Pitch Perfect) as an outgoing fellow intern who, like in all his other roles, needs to imporve his social skills, Zach Pearlman, Andrew Rannells as Jules' assistant, and Christina Scherer as Jules' secretary. After this, I really want to see Rannells and Scherer in more quality roles. The director, Nancy Meyers, scored a home run when casting this movie. Regardless of one's previous experience in business, it is easy to understand how all of these people relate and what the individual business struggles mean. The entire narrative feels modern and is perfect for 2015. As a comedy, the part of the movie that should stand out and make people want to see it is the humor. In the two hour run time the audience laughed out loud 125 times. The jokes cover all ranges of topics and are presented through the creative situations, snappy dialogue, and perfectly timed visuals. But the movie is not simply another attempt to push as many jokes as possible into 2 hours. As cliche as it sounds, the movie has heart, lots of heart. Ben, Jules, and the others care for each other. We learn about Ben's 40+ years with his wife, his life as a retiree, Jule's struggling family life, the other interns' personal struggles, and more. In some comedies I lose interest in the dramatic moments and am just waiting for another laugh. But in 'The Intern' the comedy is equally captivating interesting as the more emotional sequences. The technical aspects also cannot be overlooked. The production design gave each location a unique and interesting look. Though his work is frequently such a perfect fit for the scene that it is unnoticed, Theodore Shapiro delivers a whimsical and delightful soundtrack for whatever the tone of the scene requires. After his most recent work, Shapiro is quickly becoming a respectably accomplished composer for comedy (he is possibly becoming the new Christophe Beck). There is very little to feel unsatisfied about with the film. The change in tone is occassionally jarring and I was lost to a few of the jokes. But other than a few trite criticisms, almost any demographic will come away from this feel good movie smiling. 'The Intern' was among my favorite comedies that I have seen in the recent past. Work place comedies have become so common that one of the most beloved sit com TV series of all time was simply called "The Office". But here the performances and situations feel fresh with the new twists of the aged intern, family struggles, and contrasting lives. It demonstrates the value of experience, management, passion, leadership, wit, and carrying a hankerchief (as well as blinking - "Jules hates it when people don't blink"). - A- Nancy Meyer comedy THE INTERN from Warner Bros. Pictures stars Robert De Niro, Anne Hathaway, Rene Russo, Adam DeVine, Nat Wolff, Anders Holm, Andrew Rannells, Zach Pearlman, & Christina Scherer and is out in theaters September 25th, 2015. PG-13 - 2hrs. 1min. 9/16/2015 You can read more of my movie reviews at: GoSoundtracks.com.

Robert De Niro rarely disappoints and doesn't here. But the film - perhaps unwittingly - reveals the ways in which driven businesswomen poison their relationships with spouse, parents, and children, yet nevertheless maintains that Hathaway's character is a victim of sexual stereotyping. It doesn't wash. If you kept the same script, but reversed the husband/wife roles feminists would be frothing at the mouth. As it is, you just end up feeling sorry for the husband, the "rising star in marketing" who gave it all up to be a right-thinking progressive house-husband. There was no reason why the career woman here - she WAS President of her own company, after all - couldn't have taken her tot to her touchy-feely office after pre-school and no reason why her husband had to sacrifice his own dreams. Good grief! What century are they living in!

B When walking into the Intern you should know that this movie won't get oscar buzz, but instead just know that's it's such a fun movie. The Intern follows this senior citizen that becomes an intern with his boss that's younger than him and as the film goes instead of creating a sappy and akward lover story, we get a brighly developed friendship between Anne Hathaway and Robert de Niro that makes this film funner than sappier. Again, this is jusf like any Nancy Meyers feel good comedy but what makes this film such a good and enjoyable one is Robert de Neio once again giving such a great performance that his character is so likeable that he is clearly the one that saves this movie. Also Anne Hathaway was good but not great because in the begginjng she starts out being rude and a cartoony character but as the film goes on, you start to like her because you understand why she acts like that and how well developed her chemistry with Robert de Niro gets. Problems with this movie are that there are many sub-plots like Anne Hathaway with her family that you don't care about and other sub-plots that are completed and are pointless to the main story of this movie. Also that the story's structure starts to lose it's focus with it going on different kinds of directions. Lot's of funny jokes are in this film but also bad ones that keep on going and just make this movie akward. Also that the conclusion to The Intern starts to drag on when you start to wonder when the film is ever gonna end because it adds so much more content for the sake of making this film longer and just like any feel good comedy, In the end besides those flaws, The Intern won't give you anything new but it's the perfect family movie that will make everyone laugh, think about the film's morals and get entertained by. Nothing in The Intern is absolutely terrible, it's just a movie that you should go watch with a family and just have fun with it for what it is. Rating: 76% and a B

3 out of 5 stars. Nancy Meyers' films have a certain formula. Take a good setup idea, add some of the best star actors and have lots of top technical work like Art Direction, Set Decoration, Costume Design and Cinematography. By the 2nd Act, start adding the usual rom-com mechanics, schmaltzy music and a heavy dose of sentiment. By the 3rd Act, throw in some unnecessary slapstick and side stories that go on too long. End the film with everyone happy, a few more tears while characters learn life lessons, and close with lots of hugging. This has been the pattern with "What Women Want (Mel Gibson, Helen Hunt)," Something's Gotta Give (Diane Keaton, Jack Nicholson)," "It's Complicated (Meryl Streep, Alec Baldwin)," and now "The Intern (Robert De Niro, Anne Hathaway)." Not an awful way to spend two hours, just a very predictable one. In this case, the film is worth seeing for Robert De Niro, who has evolved into the genial senior actor of his generation with "Meet The Parents," "Analyze This," and especially "Silver Linings Playbook," which is the best film of his late comic period. His subtle work and skill with all the other cast remind you of how great an actor he has been for over 40 years.

The Intern is that sentimental comedy drama film that tries to have that heartwarming, feel good outlook as the characters are going through some career challenges. When it comes to these types of films, they can be predictable. Very predictable, that when watching these characters going through some struggles with their career and their personal lives. It is easily foreshadowed that everything will be okay in the end. The film starts with a 70 year old widower Ben (Robert De Niro), who is always trying to keep himself busy in retirement. He applies to a senior intern at an online fashion company, who the CEO is Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway). Jules is an every day busy businesswoman, she is always focused on her work, and tidy when it comes to planning, and having everything done the way she wants it too. Jules is also trying to maintain her personal life with her daughter and husband Matt. Her husband takes on the role of a stay home daddy, taking the daughter and participating in all the events with her at school. Ben assist Jules in her every day work by driving her around, giving advice, and life experience lessons, and also trying to help her out with her daughter. When Jules is coming across a breaking point of wanting another CEO to take charge of her company that she started. Jules struggles can be predictable, and the film easily shows that every challenge she is going through will easily be handled. Ben is like that magical person that shows up, does the entire handy errand work to keep everyone on track. Sort of like a Mary Poppins ideal person. Jules personal life that she rarely has with her husband and daughter does open the room that her marriage is not exactly healthy. When her husband is having an affair, as Jules is almost non existent. Jules is under pressure, the challenges are not really much of a struggle when solutions were easily given. Making the ending of her accomplishment with deciding the fate of her career and personal life less awarding than it should. Anne Hathaway and Rober De Niro were both charming and decent with their performances.

What is Rene Russo doing in this? .....it's also an extravaganza of product placement galore mainly for Apple Computer, fancy linens and jazzed-up bathtubs, escalades, a little token tai-chi thrown in, as you feast on the row houses and brownstones of Park Slope, you can buy those too....

Completely pleasant from beginning to end, there's nothing in The Intern that'll challenge or provoke you...but you know what? That's okay: too few movies these days mistake 'somber' with 'satisfying' and director Nancy Myers-of Something's Gotta Give and It's Complicated fame-is someone who gets that. Frankly, we could use more filmmakers like her.

"Robert De Niro is back in his comfort zone in this pleasant comedy from Nancy Meyers" Movie Review: The Intern Date Viewed: September 30 2015 Written and Directed By Nancy Meyers (What Women Want, The Holiday, It's Complicated and Something's Gotta Give) Starring: Robert De Niro, Anne Hathaway, Rene Russo, Anders Holm, Andrew Rannells, Adam DeVine, Zack Pearlman, Jason Orley, JoJo Kushner, Nat Wolff, Steve Vinovich, Linda Lavin, Celia Weston and Molly Bernard. Writer and director Nancy Meyers is like a cute little poodle, even though the dog performs the same tricks, she still loves her owner. Meyers' movies have become comfort food for female audiences. After making "What Women Want", "Something's Gotta Give" and "It's Complicated", Meyers is back with another female-centric comedy. "The Intern" is a gentle and funny work-place comedy that works mostly because of the likable chemistry between Robert De Niro and Anne Hathaway. Meyers has finally put Bobby back in his comfort zone after making so many terrible movies (The Big Wedding, Grudge Match, Little Fockers, Last Vegas and The Bag Man). Robert De Niro plays Ben Whittaker, a widower and retired executive who decides to get back in the working game because nothing much happens in his life anymore. Even though he is in his 70s, Ben Whittaker decides to become an intern at a fast-growing online fashion company. Ben is assigned to work with founder and CEO Jules Ostin (Anne Hathaway), who is at first skeptical about him due to his age. Eventually, Jules comes to like Ben and she let's him become her chauffeur. Likeable and reliable, everybody in the work place likes Ben and he gets attracted to Fiona (Rene Russo) who is the in-house massage therapist. Jules is married to her stay-at-home husband, Matt (Anders Holm) and has a little daughter named Paige (JoJo Kushner). When Ben is assigned to drive Paige to a kids' birthday, he discovers Matt kissing another woman. It all indicates that Matt can't hold on to his marriage because Jules is absent all the time due to her being CEO. "The Intern" is a pleasant and charming comedy from Nancy Meyers. De Niro and Hathaway have great chemistry together and "The Intern" doesn't have the sitcom feel I saw from the commercials. It is not great cinema but "The Intern" was sweet enough for me to recommend it.

I was really rooting for this movie going in because I enjoyed Nancy Meyers' previous films Something's Gotta Give and It's Complicated, but this movie has some issues. The first hour of this movie is a mess and worthy of a 2 star review with its cringeworthy "old people are so outdated when it comes to the younger generation's lingo and work process" jokes that just do not land at all. I may have smiled twice in that first hour. DeNiro is giving it his all and though some of the dialogue is not good, he does a decent job delivering them. Hathaway is fine too but also is given a really messy timeline of work ethic that doesn't mesh all together. The ensemble is filled with great people like Adam Devine, Andrew Rannells, Rene Russo, and a hilarious but small part from Linda Lavin. Anders Holm who I like didn't really fit his part well and I think they under utilized Rannells and Russo. The movie starts to get better in the second hour after DeNiro and Hathaway form a bond and work pattern together and have some really touching scenes. Overall, the first half of this movie needed some serious rewriting because it was as if Nancy Meyers was a 100 year old out of touch woman that just based the young characters off of stereotypes in other movies and it needed to be cut down because it got to its point but never decided to leave it. We get it. DeNiro is lonely so he's happy to do any work he can do around the office and Hathaway doesn't want his help. You don't need to spend an hour trying to explain that to the audience. The ending is a little abrupt and cleaned things up too fast but it was fine, nothing terrible. It's a good rental

Ben: I still have music in me, absolutely positive about that! The intern tiene a Jules (Anne Hathaway) como la CEO de un negocio de internet que de la noche a la mañana se volvió exitoso, y deciden crear un programa para que personas de tercera edad puedan trabajar como internos dentro de la compañia. Ben (Robert De Niro) es viudo, y sin mucho que hacer en sus días, envía un video para ser considerado, y es escogido como pasante. Lo inesperado es que a la final Ben sorprende a todos y logra no solo mejorar el negocio, sino le da una lección valiosa a Jules. Nancy Meyers la directora es especialista en estas comedias que te hacen sentir bien. Tienden a ser un poco idealistas, pero no hay duda que son entretenidas y siempre tiene personajes encantadores. La historia de hecho me sorprendió sobretodo en el primer acto, porque me encontré enfocada en Ben, queriendo verlo triunfar, y desde el principio es infalible. Todos lo quieren y esta ahí para enseñar lecciones sabias. El problema es que cuando la película sigue avanzando, nunca vemos un lado mas vulnerables o con fallas de Ben, entonces termina siendo perfecto, algo que no existe. En contraste, Jules quien al parecer lo tiene todo bajo control, es toda una ilusión, ya que al tener este negocio exitoso, no tiene el tiempo para estar con su familia y ser una madre y esposa atenta. Pero estas fallas la hacen alguien con quien puedes relacionarte.La historia de infidelidad me pareció que estaba de más, porque no tenia ninguna relevancia y no le agrego nada a la historia. The Intern es mas de lo que aparenta, pero no sabe bien como balancear el drama y la comedia. Se les paso un poco la mano en el tercer acto, ya que parece una película completamente distinta de la de la primera media hora, donde es un placer ver la relación que tiene Ben con los otros pasantes que son décadas mas jóvenes que él y tiene un tono ligero. Igualmente es una de esas películas que disfrutas, pero que no te vas a acordar de ella al día siguiente.

I'd say it was a sweet business-type family movie. At first, I thought it was exactly likeThe Devil Wears PradaÂ and Hathaway was the mean boss and DeNiro was the intern. But Hathaway's role was not rude and abrupt like that of Streep. Instead, at times the looked like father and daughter as the film progressed. Those two worked extremely well together in the film. They have the on-screen magic! That is for sure! There are so many funny scenes in the movie that I cannot narrow them down to the Top 3, but my all time favorite one was when Rene Russo entered and "introduced" her hands to DeNiro's body. Lmao! Talk about hands-on, if you get my drift. There was a twist in the film- but a good twist and NOT a bad one; it was so sweet that theÂ entireÂ audience said, "Awwwww." It was too cute what the audience said.Â DeNiro really captured and connected with theÂ audience in this film. People including me wereÂ talkingÂ to him as if he was right there with us in theÂ theater; people were clapping for him in certain scenes; it was just a very highÂ entertainingÂ and sweet film. Anne Hathaway was astounding! ReneÂ Russo was dynamite! The opening of the film with a special lady who was after Ben (DeNiro) was absolutelyÂ hilarious!Â This is one of those movies where all you need is the popcorn and the sweet sounds of your laughter because the entire castÂ deliversÂ that to you! I am laughing thinking about all the things I amÂ recallingÂ from seeingÂ the film! You will NOT be disappointed! Everyone brings it and scores!

The feel good new business model old people and working females can lead full lives film of the year goes to. Defintely escapist and ideal and doesnt show a lot of the bumps along the way, but the film strictly succeeds on another Hollywood trope being the likability of the leads in this case the gentlemenly senior in Robert Deniro and the eager if wound up Anne Hathaway who both deliver above the bar performances and dimension to the roles they were given. Probably will rank along side or at least close to Devil Wears Prada where the polish and the acting brings up a film and is escapist enough to check realism at the door and you ride along on the journey which works for this one. Surprisingly enjoyable,.

This heartfelt movie feature 2 genuine, heartfelt performances from Deniro and Hathaway. They both are believable in their roles. You tell they bought into this movie. Hathaway is the owner/creator of a new business, and Deniro is a widow who takes a internship at the company as part of a senior intern program. The movie puts old school values against new age values and the results are fun Deniros characters is an extremely calm, nice, non controversial man who cares about others well beings. He also teaches the youngsters about values and other things from his past. This relationship is very cool too see. The movie isn't deep in plot, but it does explore things life family, overworking, and challenging the norm. I enjoyed the film for the on screen relationships which were truly fantastic.
